DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON SOUTH WEST TASMANIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on South West Tasmania, be appointed to inquire into and report upon-
(a) the natural values of South West Tasmania to Australia and the world;
(b) federal responsibility in assisting Tasmania to preserve its wilderness areas of national and international importance, including appropriate financial assistance; and
(c) the future energy needs of Tasmania and energy options outside South West Tasmania.
(2) That the Committee consist of six Senators, as follows:
(a) three to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b) two to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate; and
(c) one to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.
(3) That the Committee proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4) That the Chairman of the Committee be appointed by and from the members of the Committee.

(5) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(6) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(7) That three members of the Committee be necessary to constitute a meeting of the Committee for the exercise of its powers.

(8) That the Committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations it may deem fit.

(9) That the Comnmittee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the matters which the Committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a sub-committee be a majority of the Senators appointed to the sub-committee.

(10) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee with the approval of the President.
(11) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.
(12) That, except where the Committee by vote otherwise decides, its hearings of evidence be open to the public.
(13) That the Committee report to the Senate by the first sitting day in 1982.

(14) That, if the Senate be not sitting when the Committee has completed its report, the Committee may send its report to the President of the Senate or, if the President is not available, to the Deputy-President, who is authorised to give directions for its printing and circulation and, in such event, the President or Deputy-President shall lay the report upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.
(15) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsisent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

CHAPTER III
Deputy-President (Procedure) and Deputy-President (Committees)

26. Absence of President and Officers

29. Unless and until the Senate otherwise orders, the Deputy-President (Procedure) shall perform the duties and exercise the authority of President in relation to all proceedings of the Senate, and the Deputy-President (Committees) shall perform the duties and exercise the authority of President in relation to the Standing, Select and Estimates Committees of the Senate and the Joint Committees of the Senate and the House of Representatives, until the next meeting of the Senate (whenever the Senate shall be informed by the Clerk at the Table of the absence of the President), and so on from day to day, on the like information being given to the Senate, until the Senate shall otherwise order:

Is the Minister aware of the effect that outside money, if I may call it that, has had on forcing up the price of houses in some areas of Australia and that this money also competes for funds available for borrowing? Is the Minister able to give the Senate some idea of how many houses are owned by persons who do not reside in Australia? Will the Minister ask the Government to make it illegal immediately for non-residents to buy up Australian homes? Finally, is this perhaps yet another reason that Australian residents should have some system of social security numbers by which they could be identified at other times, but particularly when they are wanting to buy a house in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not have the figures requested by Senator Townley with regard to how many houses would be owned by non-residents in this country. I will see whether there is any information that could be gained on that although I have some feeling that this information would be difficult to ascertain. I note the other part of the honourable senator's question which related to some sort of social security number to identify Australian citizens at the time they purchase houses or property. I have not heard that that would be one of the ways in which some sort of identification would be of value. However, I will see whether some inquiry could be made with regard to that suggestion.

ANSWER.PARA: I will ascertain from the Treasurer what information is available on foreign investment as it relates to the purchase of real estate or property, although again I doubt whether it would be in the detailed form that may be implied in Senator Townley's question. I will take that question on notice and see what can be provided to the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. Is it a fact that as a result of the Budget pensioners and beneficiaries who rent public housing from housing commissions, et cetera, will not be eligible in future for the supplementary rent allowance? If that is so, does the Minister expect the State housing authorities to make up this deficit in pensioners' incomes? If that is so, how can the authorities do so in view of the fact that once again this year the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement contains an 18 per cent reduction in real terms in the funds for States in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter to which the honourable senator drew attention at the beginning of his question is correct and I think that is explicit in the material which was put before the Parliament in the Budget. The changes being made to the supplementary allowance have the express objective of directing the financial assistance to those pensioners who require it most, that is, those pensioners who are paying high non-subsidised rentals. Pensioners and beneficiaries who rent public housing are already in receipt of a considerable public subsidy which is partly at the cost of the Commonwealth because of the Commonwealth's involvement with respect to welfare housing and the payments it makes to the States in that area. It has been a problem for some pensioners and beneficiaries who are not able to get the benefits of that subsidised accommodation that they have been forced to rent at high rates. That has been a particular problem in Sydney. It varies from town to town and city to city.

ANSWER.PARA: The situation is that the increases in benefit will be available to those pensioners who require it most, that is, those who have least private income and who are paying high private rents. I would not expect the State housing commissions to make up the deficit in any sense. Rather I would expect the State housing commissions to continue to set their concessional rentals at levels which take into account the actual income limits or the incomes available to the pensioners and beneficiaries that they are serving. To avoid any misunderstanding I should also point out that with respect to those pensioners and beneficiaries who are currently receiving supplementary assistance and who are occupying the sort of accommodation referred to by the honourable senator in his question, namely, public housing, there is a saving provision which will ensure that they continue to receive the supplement that they receive at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. In view of the final remarks of the Minister I ask whether this means that in future we will have in public housing accommodation two groups of pensioners-one group whose occupancy of those houses preceded the Budget and, therefore, who will continue to receive the supplementary rent allowance and another group who will be worse off but perhaps in the same situation and who, because they occupied their houses after the Budget, will receive no such allowance.

—It is true that new tenants in that accommodation will not receive the supplement and those who were in that accommodation prior to the Budget will receive the supplement. The alternative available to the Government was to cease to pay the supplement to those pensioners and beneficiaries which would have resulted at least temporarily in a reduction in their income until the indexation provisions overtook it. The Government thought that that was not the most desirable way to deal with the matter.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs aware of the high degree of transfer pricing practices within the Australian motor manufacturing industry? Further, does the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs effectively monitor the free-on-board prices at which Toyota and Nissan supply components to their Australian subsidiaries? If so, what has been the outcome of the Department's inquiries?

—I think everybody in this chamber would be aware that in the Australian motor vehicle manufacturing industry there is a great deal of interchange of parts between Australia and other countries. As to the degree of reliance we can place on Senator Watson's statement that that really does occur to a high degree, I would need to check that with the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs and obtain an answer for him. In respect of the other point as to whether the Department is monitoring that situation, I can assure Senator Watson that the Department is watching that matter very closely, and I will obtain some further information on that matter for Senator Watson.

—I ask a question of the Minister for National Development and Energy, although the Minister for Finance may feel it is more appropriate for her to answer the question, which concerns the Foreign Investment Review Board. Is the Minister aware that Sir Bede Callaghan, Chairman of the Foreign Investment Review Board, recently proudly stated that 'very few' foreign investment proposals are ever rejected by the Board? Further, is the Minister aware of Sir Bede's incredible explanation that this situation is 'partly due to the Board's role in helping foreign investors frame their proposals to match the Government's requirements'? That quotation is taken from the Bulletin of 18 August. Is this merely another way of saying that the FIRB is happy to advise, presumably free of charge, large foreign investors on how to bend the rules to breaking point and hence ensure that further hundreds of thousands of hectares of Australian urban and rural land are sold off to overseas interests? In the light of Sir Bede's frank and alarming admission and in view of the fact that during the last four years no less than 14 million hectares of land, valued at $192m, were purchased by foreigners, when will the Government establish a full inquiry into the extent of foreign ownership of Australian land?

—I am not aware of the remarks made by Sir Bede Callaghan. It would be necessary for me to look at the whole context of those remarks before I could adjudicate on them. As to the second question, the answer is no. As to the third question, the first thing I should say is that ownership of and title to land in Australia are primarily State matters. An assertion as to who shall own land and who shall not, of necessity has to be a matter for the States. That is not in any way to resile from the Commonwealth's responsibility in terms of capital inflow; I want to say that. I simply acknowledge that land, in itself and its ownership, essentially are matters for the States.
—You can stop the funds coming in, though.

—Yes, that is exactly the point I am making. I want to define the difference in the two matters. Of course the Commonwealth has a capacity and a responsibility in regard to not only the quantitative but also the qualitative nature of the inflow of capital. It is looking at that very strenuously. For example, an analysis of the $6,000m of last year's capital inflow showed a very small detectable real estate quality to it. That is not to say that in the first instance the money could not come in under another umbrella and be used for real estate down the way. So the Government is looking very hard at the matter. We are very keen to diagnose the true nature of the inflow of capital. Of the $6 billion that came in last year, more than half immediately turned around and went out to purchase imports for capital ventures, for setting up industries. It is not easy to diagnose what funds are used for the purchase of real estate but we are looking hard at that at this moment. My comment on the States is clearly to indicate that the States have sovereignty in terms of the final ownership of land. It is possible for the States also to act. The Commonwealth can act at the point of inflow of capital; the States of course can act in terms of titles. We have the matter continuously under survey.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for the latter part of his answer. I accept that he has not seen a report of Sir Bede's remarks and therefore cannot comment on them. I ask him, as a senior Minister, what would be the Government's attitude to the Foreign Investment Review Board adopting a role of 'helping foreign investors frame their proposals to match the Government's requirements'? Does the Minister, who is a senior Minister in the Cabinet, believe that that is an appropriate role for Sir Bede and his Foreign Investment Review Board to perform?

—I have some difficulty because I do not known the context in which the statement was made. A perfectly proper and innocent explanation of it would be that everybody in public office has a responsibility to assist individual members of the community to avail themselves of the facilities of the existing law.
—Like Pat Lanigan used to in Social Security?

—As usual, Senator Evans has more inside knowledge than anyone else. No doubt he will therefore avail the Senate of the privileged knowledge. Let me say to the honourable senator that the history of Sir Bede Callaghan is one of outstanding service to Australia both as a banker and as a man of very great intellectual capacity and integrity. In my judgment there are very few greater serving Australians today. I do not say that in any sense of denying that we should be critical of anything that anyone says, but we are dealing with a person who would put Australia first. Therefore I take the benign explanation in the event of not having any further information.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. It relates to the independent inquiry, known as the Harders inquiry, established by the Government in October 1980 to investigate matters relating to the disclosure of electoral expenditure. The inquiry was instituted pursuant to the Government's commitment to public disclosure of electoral expenditure and its need for advice as to the appropriate machinery for administration of its requirements.

QUESTION.PARA: In view of the time which has elapsed since Sir Clarrier Harders first commenced his investigations and in view of the commitment made by the then Minister for Administrative Services on 29 August 1980 that the report would be completed and considered early in 1981, I ask the Minister: Has the completed report been received by the Government? When will it be made available to the Parliament for detailed consideration? What action will be taken by the Government to ensure that the provisions which might be included in the Commonwealth Electoral Act to require public disclosure of electoral expenditure come into operation prior to the next federal election?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has received a report from Sir Clarrie Harders in accordance with the terms of reference detailed by the then Minister for Administrative Services in his second reading speech to the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill on 15 May 1980. As the honourable senator reminds us in his question, the Minister at that time referred to the Government's wish to have available the advice of an independent inquiry prior to making any decision. The position, therefore, is that the Government has received the report, is still considering it and has not, so far, made a decision. Whether the report to the Government will be tabled in the Parliament is a matter which is also being considered. Without committing the Government one way or the other and without saying the report will not be tabled-I am not saying that at all-all I can say is that, at the time the Harders inquiry was established, no commitment was given that the report to the Government-that is to say the report to the Government for its advice and not to the Parliament-would be tabled or otherwise made public. But, the matter will be examined.
—Will the information be taken into account when a decision is made?

—The honourable senator asks whether the information will be taken into account when a decision is made. The report is being considered now by the Government. In respect of the other part of the honourable senator's question, the extent of timing of any amendment to the Commonwealth Electoral Act which might or might not be proposed still remains a matter for decision. As soon as my colleague whom I represent can give us further information, I will make it available.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Is the Minister aware that some long term mail contractors in New South Wales country areas are being forced out of business because new applicants are submitting absurdly low tenders, which Australia Post accepts? Further, is the Minister aware that these new mail contractors are then deliberately operating their businesses at a loss so that they can write this loss off on their income tax returns? Will the Minister ensure that future mail contracting jobs are awarded to sincere men and women instead of to people who are manipulating the contracts in order to out-smart the Taxation Office and who, in most cases, are providing inferior services to those provided by the original long term contractors?

—I think honourable senators would understand that the Government, when putting matters out to tender, would be influenced by the lowest tender. That would certainly be a factor which would make such a tender favourable. I am not aware of the particular circumstances to which Senator Sibraa refers; that is, that long term mail contractors are being forced out of business and losing their contracts by-if I understand the honourable senator correctly-what he calls absurdly low and artificially low tenders. I believe that matter should be referred to my colleague, the Minister for Communications. I will undertake to bring to his attention that and also the other matters embraced in the honourable senator's question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Having in mind that people living and working in remote rural areas of Australia are involved in industries which earn a huge slice of export income for all Australians each year, thus contributing towards the high standard of living most Australians enjoy-a standard of living which, in most cases, includes a telephone for an annual rental of $120 for business use or $85 for private use-does the Minister for Communications not agree that the time has come for a complete overhaul and updating of the telephone installation policy, aimed at setting a standard installation fee and yearly rental for all subscribers, regardless of residence?

—Honourable senators will acknowledge the interest of Senator Bjelke-Petersen in non-metropolitan Australia. Indeed, all honourable senators should have an interest in the welfare of non-metropolitan Australia, and of the people who live and work outside the large cities, as well as the particular difficulties that they face. The honourable senator draws to our attention a particular problem in relation to the supplying and rental cost of telephones. That does involve a policy decision which can be made only by the Minister within whose portfolio the matter falls and I will pass on her suggestion to that Minister for consideration.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. In view of the recommendation in the recent World Council of Churches report, 'Justice for Aboriginal Australians', that State and Federal governments should expand Aboriginal housing as a matter of urgency, and in view of the fact that the Federal Minister stated publicly on the Nationwide television program on 10 August 1981 that he accepted the general thrust of that report, why has the value of funds for Aboriginal housing decreased by 6.6 per cent in real terms in this year's Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I first comment that the World Council of Churches delegation, which was here for a very brief time, could not have hoped to see everything that was going on in Aboriginal Australia--
—You said you supported the general thrust.

—I am about to acknowledge that, if the honourable senator can just contain her impatience. In three weeks the delegation did not do a bad job of getting a feel for what is going on in this country. I certainly stand by the comments that I made on the Nationwide program that, in general terms, I endorse the assessment that there is a serious problem in this regard in Australia. Of course, as I said on that program, that is why we have a Department of Aboriginal Affairs. It is why this Government is committed to Aboriginal advancement and why it has done and is doing so much in this regard.

ANSWER.PARA: We have been able to provide large amounts of housing stock over the last decade and will be able to continue to supply significant amounts throughout Australia. The honourable senator would know that the provision for housing this year will be split between the Aboriginal Development Commission, which will use some of the housing funding for grants-in-aid, and my colleague the Minister for Housing and Construction, who will distribute some of it through the States for public and welfare housing, for Aboriginals specifically. The allocation will be sufficient to build a large number of houses. I am advised by some of my officers, for example those in the eastern and other regions, that they believe the housing backlog for Aboriginals can be overcome, if not in the next few years, perhaps within the next 10 years. The allocation of funds as between the different functions of my Department has been examined as a matter of priority. I have wanted to devote more money to Aboriginal health, particularly by way of grants-in-aid. I draw to the attention of the Senate that this year we will be able to increase by more than 20 per cent grants-in-aid for both Aboriginal health and Aboriginal legal services. I believe that this is the kind of thrust which was being urged upon me by honourable members opposite throughout the last session.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ELDERLY CITIZENS: AVAILABILITY OF COMMERCIAL CALL DEVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security aware that the various commercial call devices which are available to certain elderly or handicapped citizens enable them to remain in their own homes longer before needing nursing home or institutional care? Will the Minister consider a system whereby such devices may be made available to the aged or handicapped?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only recently become aware of the availability of the sorts of devices mentioned by the honourable senator. In fact, a couple of weeks ago in Perth I saw one of these units demonstrated. I understand there are a number of competitive units available on the market now. I gather that the general approach adopted by people who make and sell these units is to provide some form of connection between the person who perhaps is concerned about his or her health and some centralised point which will enable that person to raise an alarm if he or she suffers a collapse or has some difficulty in communication. Obviously, this sort of service could be very relevant to people who are frail and who perhaps are living alone at home and who might be nervous about continuing to do that because of the risk of some physical injury or illness or something of that sort.

ANSWER.PARA: It appears to me that this is a development which could be very useful to many people in the community. Accordingly, I have drawn to the attention of my Department the availability of these devices. I have requested my Department to pass on that advice to the Australian Council on the Ageing which, in conjunction with the Commonwealth Government and at the expense of the Commonwealth, is currently doing a survey into the needs of the aged at home. It is aimed very much at determining what is required by the aged to enable them to maintain independent living. I cannot say that consideration has been given at this stage to whether there ought to be some government intervention in what is at the moment an initiative of private business people or a number of different private businesses. But I believe such devices could have some useful application which might indeed be of interest to the Government and to the Department in the longer term. I inform the honourable senator that the point she has raised is in the initial stages of examination and will be examined further.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FINANCE: FARMERS IN DROUGHT AFFECTED AREAS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask: As a result of Government policy can a farmer in a drought affected area who has net assets in excess of $1m, or even $2m, get carry-on finance at 4 1/2 per cent interest and a bank overdraft of up to $100,000 at 10 1/2 per cent interest while home buyers with negligible net assets pay 12 1/2 per cent for bank loans and more than 12 1/2 per cent for building society loans?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will need to refer that question to the Treasurer for confirmation of the matters stated by Senator Walsh. I will see that an early response is given to him.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Why is it that when everyone else with any knowledge of these matters knows that the answer is yes the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer does not know?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I can respond with a question. If the answer was already known why was the question posed?

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It has been reported that there are large numbers of Polish people leaving their homeland because of the problems within that country. If it is their wish to enter Australia are they required to go through the normal procedures of applying for entry or are they considered refugees? If they are not of refugee status at this stage, can the Minister indicate what the Government's attitude would be if Poland were indeed invaded?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Large numbers of Poles are presently entering western Europe, particularly Austria and West Germany. However, it is not clear how many of these people are seeking to remain abroad. The movement of Poles into central and western European countries is normal at this time of the year but this has been facilitated in recent months of course by the more liberal approach to the issue of passports by Polish authorities, as well as by other events. Although the number of those who have sought refugee status is relatively small, the number of Poles seeking refugee status in countries such as Austria has increased significantly. Those seeking to enter Australia as independent migrants or for family reunion are able to apply at migration offices in various European capitals. Such applications are given sympathetic consideration.

ANSWER.PARA: Those who seek to be included in Australia's refugee program must first satisfy the requirements of the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees that they have adequate claims for refugee status before they can be considered for inclusion in our program. Just as a matter of further information, Australia's intake of Polish refugees in 1980-81 was 4,600. Although no final decision has yet been taken by the Government on the size of the 1981-82 program, it is expected to be of a similar order. Of course, as the events in Poland unfold, the situation will be kept under continuing review.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. If the Government's recent measures against tax avoidance are going to be as effective as has been claimed, why has the budgetary provision for revenue lost through tax avoidance been maintained overall at exactly the same dollar figure as last year while the particular provision for revenue lost through personal income tax avoidance has, in fact, increased from $170m last financial year to $220m this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I think it is accepted that the Government's efforts with regard to tax avoidance over the past year have been successful. The Treasurer has made clear that it is the continuing objective of the Government to see that those who are required to pay tax under the taxation legislation do so. I will need to check the figures that have been quoted by Senator Evans regarding this year's Budget. If there is any explanation from the Treasurer in response to the question posed by Senator Evans I will see that he is advised.

—I ask a supplementary question. I refer the Minister to page 231 of Budget Paper No. 1 for the checking of her figures. In checking with the Treasurer, will she also clarify by what measure she is claiming there has been an improvement in tax avoidance if the figures in the Budget are as I have quoted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will seek that information from the Treasurer. I will ask him to clarify the points raised in the question arising from the statements on page 231.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Transport whether he has seen reports of the comments by a member of the Local Government Association of South Australia Incorporated that it is costing some $500,000 to administer the $6.2m allocated as road grants to South Australia. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether most of this amount is being spent on works supervision of local government projects by government officials? He may care to comment on whether this is reflected in other States. Is the Minister aware that local government in South Australia raises and spends some $46m on roads and manages to carry out this work without such supervision? Can the Minister inform the Senate of any moves to improve the efficiency of the administration of road grants in South Australia so that as much money as is available is actually spent on road maintenance and construction?

—I am informed that the Minister for Transport has seen the Press reports to which Senator Jessop has just referred and that the reports concern comments made recently to the South Australian Public Accounts Committee by a member of the Local Government Association. Mr Hunt has informed me that it is true that in the past some of the Commonwealth local road grant money to South Australia has been absorbed by administrative costs incurred by the South Australian Highways Department in administering local government programs. I am not aware whether the figure to which Senator Jessop referred-that is, $46m-is correct. I will need to check that for him. Senator Jessop might be interested to know that the Federal Government has made some changes to the Roads Grants Act 1981 to require that local road grant money can no longer be used to meet administration charges of the kind referred to in the Press reports to which the honourable senator referred. The entire grant must now be spent on road works.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. As a result of recent Government decisions, would it be true to say that the Government is now opposed to home ownership for all Australians? How can the Government justify the highest ever interest rates for home owners, a new tax on building materials and a new tax on furnishings for a home? How can a government claiming to represent all the people justify these charges, which will add about $10,000 to the cost of a modest home, particularly when we have the most serious housing crisis ever known?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only statement by a parliamentary member opposing home ownership came from a gentleman who I think said he did not want people to become little capitalists. He was not a member of the Government parties. The answer to the honourable senator's question is no. In the year that has just passed I think the number of homes increased by something like 11 per cent-I do not want to be held to that precise figure, but I can get it-and applications in the June quarter were high at something like 5 1/2 per cent. So the trends are still good. Having said that, I do not want to be complacent. The fact of the matter is that over the 1960s this Government raised Australia's home ownership to the highest in the world-something in the order of 75 per cent. It is true that high interest rates and the pressure of resources development will make things hard, both for those who have homes already and for those who do not have homes, because we must consider the availability of money as well as the interest rates.

ANSWER.PARA: Basically, the thrust of the Budget last night, in producing as near as possible the elimination of the overall deficit, was aimed at taking the heat off Government borrowing to a point where it could ease the demand in the market rate and in the longer term produce an abatement of interest rates. That is the aim of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long? You were guaranteeing it four years ago.

—Those who cry out should look to their own record. Their record in interest rates was a disastrous one. I simply draw attention to the recorded number of houses built and the permits issued for building in recent times. I underline the real problem to the community in high interest rates, and I therefore say that no doubt the Opposition will join with the Government in commending a Budget which is unanimously identified by economists and by bankers as being aimed at abating interest rates.

—I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister denying that a new tax on building materials and home furnishings will contribute towards difficulties for home owners in erecting a home and living in it? Is this not inflationary?

—I did not affirm or deny the situation. While I am on my feet I should like to correct the figures I gave previously. Housing activity rose strongly by 11 per cent in 1980-81 and remains buoyant. Dwelling approvals in the June quarter 1981 were 5.9 per cent above the June quarter 1980. In terms of costs generally, the fact is that inflation in Australia in the last financial year fell by 2 per cent to 8.8 per cent. That was the envy of the free world. The real measure, in looking at costs to people, is to understand that at a time when the inflation rate was 8.8 per cent the average rise in wages was in excess of 13 per cent. Therefore there was a gain to the average Australian in real purchasing power last year in excess of 4 per cent. Those figures will be found in the Budget and they are a clear indication. Incidentally, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has indicated that Australia has one of the strongest economies in the world.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations: In view of the current crop of wage demands being made on the economy and the recent wave of disastrous strikes, will the Minister consider negotiating with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the employer groups to produce a code for renegotiation of industrial agreements, a code which will require parties involved in negotiation or parties in dispute to reach agreement by way of a laid down series of steps? Will due consideration be given to a workable set of sanctions against both parties should undue delay occur?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although the question was addressed to me the request contained in it obviously is a request which the honourable senator intends to direct to the Minister for Industrial Relations, whom I represent in this place. I certainly will ask Mr Viner to consider the suggestion made by the honourable senator. The question raises the issue of whether the Government should attempt to gain union and employer agreement to a set of procedures designed to minimise industrial disruption during the processing of wage claims. There is some precedent for the sort of approach which Senator Archer has suggested to the Senate today. A number of Federal awards contain dispute procedures or grievance procedures which seek to avoid disputation over claims and to direct parties along certain paths of negotiation, with the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission playing a role in that process.

ANSWER.PARA: A good example of a recently agreed grievance procedure is that contained in the composite agreement for reduced working hours between the State Electricity Commission of Victoria and the Victorian Trades Hall Council. The dispute settlement procedure is a key element in the agreement and is to cover all disputes in that area of employment. There are other examples around Australia-for example, the Altona chemical complex. I mention that to the Senate because it indicates that the broad approach which the honourable senator has suggested is an approach which, in a more limited sense, is already in application in the industrial area. There may well be room for an expansion of that approach to the improvement of industrial relations in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It is based on the principle that the Minister exercises authority to deny entry to Australia of people who may cause turbulent happenings in Australia. I refer to the fateful party in Saudi Arabia a couple of years ago when one Helen Smith was murdered. Subsequently, when the father of that girl, Ron Smith, came to Australia in pursuit of Dr Arnot and his wife, who were the hosts of that party, and according to our colleagues of the Fourth Estate there was every indication that it was another 'High Noon', what action or surveillance was applied to ensure that things did not get out of hand, mindful of the sentiments of Ron Smith?

—The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has no information about the visit of Mr Ron Smith to Australia. He is seeking such information and if any comes to hand I will provide it to Senator Mulvihill. Although there were newspaper articles about the visit with, as Senator Mulvihill said, suggestions of a 'High Noon' situation, I think they might have been another example of the excessive imagination of some of the journalists in this country. As to the other persons concerned, Dr Arnot and his wife, there is information relating to them which I can give in response to the honourable senator's question. Dr Arnot was approved for temporary entry to Australia for three months. He has been sponsored by medical services in Sydney for locum service. Character checks in the United Kingdom revealed that nothing adverse was recorded against him. Dr Arnot has applied for resident status and the Minister has his application under review.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINES AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDERS ACTS

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs inform the Senate of the Commonwealth Government's intention in light of the Queensland Government's expressed intention to repeal its Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders Acts? Further, what guarantee do the Aboriginal people of Queensland have that the Commonwealth will protect their interests?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since late last year when the Premier of Queensland announced an intention to repeal the Queensland Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders Acts the Government has been watching the situation closely and has maintained very close contact with colleagues in Queensland. We have made sure that the Commonwealth's concerns are known and I intend to continue in that way. The picture is not yet clear, and the Queensland Government has not yet made clear what it intends to do. On 23 July I issued a statement to the Press setting out a Governments position. I seek leave to have that brief Press statement incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Statement by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator the Hon. Peter Baume
The Commonwealth Government believes that four principles must be upheld in the resolution of the future of the Queensland State Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island Reserves. These are:
The integrity of the present reserve boundaries be maintained;
Secure tenure for occupants and preservation of their rights to use the land;
Local communities to play a significant role in the management of the Reserves;
Full consultation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people before any decisions are made.
There may be several ways to satisfy these goals. I do not intend to endorse or to criticise any proposal until it has been outlined in full for public discussion.

Although it is not yet clear what the Queensland Government will finally propose, the Queensland Premier's tentative thinking about 50-year leases is better than the present situation where reserve status can be abolished overnight. Of course, perpetual leasehold or freehold would be even better.

I welcome the promise of the Premier to consult widely with Reserve communities and look forward to learning the results of these consultations. They will be particularly important in identifying appropriate systems for the management of the lands and communities.
I have consulted and will continue to consult with Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders and with Queensland Ministers as appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —You might put some interpretation in too.

—That is very kind of the honourable senator. In that statement I said that the Commonwealth believed in four principles. I think those four principles might be emphasised again. They are, first, that the integrity of the present reserve boundaries should be maintained; secondly, that there should be secure tenure for the occupants, with preservation of their rights to use the land; thirdly, that the local communities in Queensland should play a significant role in the management of their reserves; and fourthly, that there should be full consultation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities before any decisions are made.

ANSWER.PARA: Perhaps I can take the last point first. I would like to make sure that all Aboriginal and Islander people can have their say in a matter which so vitally affects their future. Consultation with the people and attention to their express wishes is thus the first necessity in reaching decisions about the future of the reserves. I note that the Queensland authorities have paid some attention to this and that the Premier himself has been at some pains to say that he is consulting the Aboriginal and Islander councils. But it would seem from information available that wide consultation has not as yet been concluded.

Of course, the other three points relate to what might happen on the reserves. Obviously integrity of the reserve boundaries means just that-that none of them must be carved off for tourist resorts or anything like that. That is something that was raised in the Press. The second principle concerns secure tenure and the third principle is that local communities should play a significant role in management. I hope that those points become clear as the weeks go by. I say to Senator Bonner that the four points which have been enunciated put down a clear Government position and a clear set of Commonwealth Government requirements in the matter which he raised.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: REGULATION AND CONTROL OF NUCLEAR ACTIVITIES IN AUSTRALIA

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the recommendation on uranium published in paragraph 4 on page 22 of the 1981 Review of Commonwealth Functions under the heading 'Home Affairs and Environment'? The paragraph states:

QUESTION.PARA: Responsibility for the regulation and control of nuclear activities in Australia to be implemented as far as possible by the States and Northern Territory, with the Commonwealth maintaining a co-ordinating role.

What responsibility in regard to regulations will be handed over to the States and what regulations will be retained by the Commonwealth? Does the Commonwealth intend to give complete control of nuclear activities to the States and the Northern Territory? Will the Minister define the areas of responsibility covering the Commonwealth's proposed co-ordinating role?

TALK.START.PARA: —The question more primarily concerns my portfolio. At the moment a study group, an interdepartmental committee, is looking at the whole question of nuclear or radioactive materials of all types in Australia and how we can best ensure maximum safeguards and maximum health regulations. That committee has not finished its work. However, to clarify matters, let me make it clear that the broad significant matters concerning nuclear non-proliferation, of course, are and will remain a Commonwealth matter. The Australian Safeguards Office is under my supervision and portfolio. It will so remain. The movement and monitoring of radioactive materials from Australia to elsewhere in the world will always be a Commonwealth matter. There will be discussions with the States and the Territory on many matters that are now handled by the States. For example, medical and industrial radioactive materials are now handled by the States. Those that have been normally treated as coming under health regulations no doubt will continue to be so treated. But overall, there is a need in a federation to devise rules under which we should work. When they are complete they will ensure that for all kinds of fissile materials and radioactive materials generally throughout Australia at both Federal and State levels there will be the highest possible standards of control and supervision that can be devised.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. It refers to the responsibility that the Government will hand to the States. Discussions are taking place at the moment in relation to safeguards. As agreement has not been reached in relation to safeguards concerning uranium which is to be shipped overseas, how will the responsibility being handed to the States affect the Government's attitude to the proposed safeguards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator misunderstands the situation. As to the whole movement of uranium from Australia overseas, firstly, no sales will be permitted and no movement negotiated until it is quite clear that the purchaser of the uranium is a member of the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and will undertake to effect all the safeguards. That is quite clear and that is a Commonwealth responsibility. Secondly, I repeat that it will remain a Commonwealth responsibility to maintain and to progress an Australian Safeguards Office under my own departmental supervision. The role of that Safeguards Office will be that of a very thorough auditor, that is, to monitor the nature, quality and changes in fissile material originating from Australia, wherever it may be on the world scene. That will remain a Commonwealth matter.

ANSWER.PARA: The matters that largely affect the States are health matters. For instance, a common health code has been sought and, I think, substantially obtained with the States in the code of mining as it concerns the mining and milling of uranium. Of course the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry report has indicated that, properly supervised, that is a matter that well can be carried out. I stress that, apart from that, the materials the States would be concerned with are those medical and industrial materials which are used day by day in either medicine or industry and which have, in fact, very short radioactive lives, as do most such materials. Therefore, they present a relatively ready and easy way of maintaining health regulations and safeguards.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. It refers to a newspaper report today that the Department of Transport will today seek talks with airlines on the subject of the critical shortage of air traffic controllers, which will probably result in a curtailment of services to some major airports, and that Brisbane Airport is most likely to be affected first. Can the Minister confirm that the first proposition to be put to the airlines today is that the 11 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew at Brisbane Airport be extended by two hours, closing from probably 10 p.m. to 7 a.m. to jet operations? Will the Minister give an assurance that if such an agreement is reached it will not operate for those months when daylight saving is in operation in other States in Australia, given that when other States advance their clocks by one hour it is necessary for people seeking interstate connections for flights originating at Brisbane to leave at 6 a.m.?

—I can confirm that there is, as I think is generally well known, a shortage of air traffic controllers in Australia. That has some ramifications all over the Commonwealth. As to whether Brisbane is being considered as one of those areas to be first involved in the kinds of decisions which Senator Martin has outlined, I am afraid that I am unable to throw any light on that matter. I will seek information from the Minister as to whether it is intended to put that policy into practice. I acknowledge the interest Senator Martin has in Queensland matters. She is concerned, as we all are, with the particular problems of travelling to Queensland during periods of daylight saving. Consequently, I will draw the special attention of the Minister to the point Senator Martin made.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, relates to subsidies paid to employers under the Special Youth Employment Training Program. What action is taken by the Department in the event that an employer subsidised under the scheme subsequently harasses an employee-I am especially concerned at recent claims of sexual harassment-to the point where the worker finds the position intolerable and is forced to leave the job? If this could occur, will the Minister consider issuing guidelines to the Commonwealth Employment Service consistent with the recent Press statement on sexual harassment from the Minister for Industrial Relations to ensure that where such complaints have been received the employer concerned is debarred from further subsidy and from any other services of the Commonwealth Employment Service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I feel sure the matter raised by Senator Giles is of considerable importance and interest to the Minister concerned. If particular instances need to be referred to the Department or to the Minister I am sure that information on them, if forthcoming, would receive urgent consideration. The honourable senator mentioned giving consideration to the issuing of guidelines. I will refer that to the Minister to see whether he feels that would be advantageous. I think we would all accept that when harassment of individuals in employment takes place-not only those funded under the Special Youth Employment Training Program but also those in any other areas-avenues exist through which reference to anti-discrimination boards or other agencies of government can be made. I will refer the question asked by Senator Giles to the Minister and seek his guidance with regard to the issuing of guidelines and will obtain also any other comments he may wish to make to the honourable senator.

—My question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport concerns Adelaide Airport. I am sure that the people of South Australia welcome the Government's announcement in the Budget Speech delivered last night that as part of a $262m civil works program this year the Adelaide Airport will be upgraded to handle international services. What more particular information is now available from the Minister? What tarmac and taxiway improvements will be undertaken; what baggage handling facilities will be provided; and what provisions for customs and quarantine procedures will be made? Will the upgrading be completed within this financial year and, if so, when should South Australians expect international flights from and to Adelaide to begin?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Teague and the rest of the people of South Australia, I welcome several features of the Budget as announced last night, including the statements concerning wine tax and the Adelaide Airport. It is intended that planning for interim improvements to the existing taxiways, aprons and the terminal building to permit the introduction of regular domestic wide-bodied jet services in June 1982 will be completed by that date. The honourable senator will notice that at this stage I refer to wide-bodied jet services, as distinct from international airline services. It is intended that the airport will be upgraded with those programs and a start will be made on containerised baggage handling facilities, further apron works, further taxiway upgrading and changes to the access road and car park.

ANSWER.PARA: Studies have shown that it is not feasible to upgrade the existing terminal building to accommodate domestic wide-bodied jets in the longer run.
