DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Button proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The absence of a coherent Government industrial relations policy and the exacerbation of industrial disputes by the Fraser Government.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition raises this matter of the absence of a coherent industrial relations policy of the Government at this stage because it is highly relevant to recent events in Australia and, indeed, is highly relevant to the Budget brought down last night and to the strategy revealed in the Budget. In recent weeks Australia has been plagued by industrial disputes-on the waterfront, within Telecom Australia, in the transport industry, in the airlines industry and within the Australian Broadcasting Commission, to name but a few-which have caused inconvenience to the Australian public and disharmony in industry and which have not been resolved or assisted by the initiatives of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The system of wage indexation has collapsed in recent weeks. The centralised system of wage fixation which we have enjoyed in this country for many years is under threat. The Government, which is supposed to provide leadership in these issues, has nowhere to go. This is not merely an allegation made lightly by an Opposition senator. The honourable member for Boothby, Mr Steele Hall, in an address to the Young Liberals in Melbourne on 29 July, said:
The Government is impotent and unsuccessful in industrial relations.

Mr Max Burr, the honourable member for Wilmot, commenting on Mr Steele Hall's remarks, said he was quite right in his criticism because it was unreasonable to expect wage restraint from unions under some policies being pursued by the present Government. Mr Andrew Peacock, the honourable member for Kooyong, about the same time issued a six page industrial relations statement in which he said, amongst other things, that 'the Government had pursued a rigid and unrealistic industrial relations line'. Those three distinguished members of the House of Representatives are, of course, not alone in their criticisms of the present Government's industrial relations policy. I quote from an editorial in the Australian Financial Review of 3 August-I use this because it seems to sum up the situation very effectively-which states:

The nearer the end of indexation came the more total the lack of direction of the Government in the vital Industrial Relations and wages areas became apparent. Rather it has weakly back-pedalled on its former tough approach in the Arbitration Commission and hoped to the very last moment that indexation, partial, flexible or otherwise, would survive in some form . . . The Arbitration Commission certainly tried hard enough to keep indexation going . . . but the Government never gave it sufficient support to make the effort any longer worthwhile.
In a comment in a leading article in the Melbourne Age of 13 August this year this was stated:

. . . the impotence of the Government, which was dramatised by Mr Fraser's eagerness to reach an accommodation with the A.C.T.U. over the transport unions strike so he could catch a plane to get to the royal wedding.

Those are just a sample of the criticisms which have been made of this Government in respect of its industrial relations policies which one might have thought came from almost impeccably objective sources.

TALK.START.PARA: —Impeccably objective?

—Impeccably objective. Senator Teague, the sources include the former Minister for Industrial Relations in the Fraser Government. They also include one of the honourable senator's parliamentary colleagues from South Australia, Mr Steele Hall. One of Senator Watson's parliamentary colleagues from Tasmania, Mr Max Burr, is also included. Comments by them were included in the comments which I described as coming from impeccable or unimpeachable sources, or something of that kind.
—Have they anything else in common?

—I do not know, Senator. That is something the honourable senator's party will have to sort out, not me. All I am saying is that those sources I referred to were consistent about one thing; they agreed with the view, a unanimous view which is widespread and shared by both unions and employer representatives-if Senator Teague wants some quotations from some of them I will give them to him later-that the Government's industrial relations policy is chaotic and a mess. They also agreed that this question of industrial relations lies at the heart of the progress and future development of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the reasons for that is, of course, that there is total confusion between wages policy and industrial relations policy in the mind of the present Government. There is total confusion between the two issues. That confusion is reflected in the Government's attitude, for example, to the amalgamations of trade unions, and its refusal to proceed with the enunciated policy of Mr Tony Street-towards amalgamations of industry-based unions. It is illustrated by writing sections into the Conciliation and Arbitration Act requiring the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to have regard to overall economic considerations in reaching its decision. That represents a confusion between the industrial relations function of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and the question of a wages policy. It is also evident by the Government's very bad record in its failure to consult with peak union organisations on industrial relations situations.

I want to make one comment flowing from last night's Budget. It is simply this: The strategy contained in last night's Budget was necessary because this Government has no incomes and wages policy. The strategy embraces the tight monetary policy and it embraces tariff review and a revalued dollar in due course. The strategy embraces those sorts of things. It embraces essentially the notion that industrial relations in Australia from now on, because of the absence of a Government industrial relations or wages policy, are to be left to market forces. I think some of the supporters of this Government in industry should start asking themselves: What does it cost a business in Australia to test the power or resolution of a trade union in the market? What does it cost a business in terms of, probably, millions of dollars? I think that is an important question which honourable senators in the Government parties have to deliberate on.

It has long been recognised in this country that the use of market forces in industrial relations areas is not acceptable, as in other areas. This abdication of leadership on industrial relations and wages issues is just another example of this country becoming a social laboratory for stupid ideological experiments. That is what it is becoming in relation to some of the ideology inherent in the razor gang and the ideology inherent in the lack of any policy in relation to wages and prices, for example.

It is quite clear that the wages policy of this Government is now in the market. There are a number of ways in which the market can dampen the growth of wage increase expectations. Firstly, it can reduce profits, thus lowering the overall prosperity in the economy and making it harder for businesses to agree to wage rises. Secondly, it can create unemployment, which worsens the bargaining position of employees. Last night's Budget was intended, I allege, to do both.

For the benefit of Government senators I propose to refer to the degree to which industrial disputes occur internationally, in terms of days lost per thousand employees annually in several countries. Let us consider that situation in order to test the market forces argument. Last year in Australia 656 days per thousand employees were lost. The unemployment level was 6 per cent. In Canada 756 days were lost. The unemployment level was 5 per cent. In the United States 396 days were lost. The unemployment level was 6 per cent. I invite honourable senators to consider those figures and then compare them with the figures for some other countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —They do not have strikes in the United States; they are just sacked.
—I know that later we will hear an intelligent contribution from the honourable senator.
—You certainly will; there is no doubt about that.

—He will have plenty of opportunities to comment then. I invite the honourable senator to listen to the figures that I shall quote. I have long suspected that, like President Ford, he cannot, in the words of President Johnson, walk down the street and chew gum at the same time. If the honourable senator can accommodate three or four sets of figures in his mind at the same time I will be surprised and gratified. I was referring to the very high level of industrial disputation in those three countries, which have high unemployment levels and no prices and incomes policies.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us consider now the position in three other countries. In Austria 0.3 days were lost per thousand employees. There was no unemployment. In Norway 34 days were lost. There was no unemployment. In Sweden seven days were lost. There was no unemployment. In Denmark 69 days were lost. There was some unemployment but not much. In Germany 19 days were lost. There was very little unemployment. These figures should be taken into account by the geniuses of the Liberal Party, such as Senator Lewis, who presumably adopt a market forces approach in relation to wage fixation. It will be noted that three of the countries mentioned-namely, Norway, Sweden and Austria-have a very low level of industrial disturbance and no unemployment. Incidentally, they have prices and incomes policies, an approach which the Fraser Government completely lacks and indeed disclaims. One must consider such figures in considering how best to get out of the current mess.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the United Kingdom in the seventies?
—I am not going to follow the honourable senator up every drain pipe today. The time available to me is limited. We can debate those matters on another occasion.
—You might get stuck.

—I am trying to debate a serious subject, one that I know Government senators do not take seriously. That is one of the problems that they face as a government. My argument, which I must make in the brief time that is available to me, is simply that, firstly, in Australia the Fraser Government has adopted social and economic policies which have destroyed the possibility of achieving a social consensus for the maintenance of the wage indexation system. Secondly, during its six years in office, the Government has promoted divisive, rhetorical and ineffectual approaches to industrial relations legislation. Thirdly, the Government has mismanaged industrial disputes to a degree which has contributed to the unstable industrial relations climate which precipitated the abandonment of wage indexation by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Fourthly, it has totally failed to provide constructive policies to fill the dangerous vacuum that has resulted from the breakdown in the wage indexation system.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to deal first with the breakdown of a social consensus in this country as to the social and economic policies necessary for the maintenance of a centralised and orderly wage system. The Fraser Government, before it came into office, made a promise about full wage indexation. It subsequently abandoned that promise. Secondly, it made promises about tax indexation. It has since abandoned those also. Thirdly, it made promises about the place of the Prices Justification Tribunal as a segment of the consensus which at the time it thought was necessary to an orderly wage fixation process. It has broken that promise also. Fourthly, by the increasingly retrogressive tax burdens that it has imposed on the poorer section of the community it has contributed further to the shattering of that consensus.

Only last night, the Government in the Budget signalled a number of actions which represent a further breaking down of the consensus which is necessary in order to maintain a system of wage indexation and centralised wage fixation which in the past it has itself argued was necessary. There has been a significant increase in sales tax. Recent increases in interest rates have meant massive increases in mortgage repayments. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), in expounding one of those ideas that come off the top of his head, was saying a fortnight ago: 'We might do a deal on interest rates if we can get some wages peace'. What an absurd proposition to put to the people of Australia! What sort of bargain is that?

Also from the Budget emerged the fact that the PAYE tax take, which was up by 22 per cent last year, represented the largest increase ever under the present government. That tax is paid by wage and salary earners. All in all, when one considers average weekly earnings, tax, loan repayments and so forth, a taxpayer with a dependent spouse and two children is now $17 a week worse off, in real terms, than he was in 1975-76. Again, last night further reference was made to the tax avoidance industry.

All of these matters are relevant to the achieving of a social consensus about industrial relations policies. The Prime Minister knows that himself. On 16 August of this year, in his electorate talk, he recognised that fact in saying that wages and industrial claims must be considered in the light of the interests of the community as a whole and take into account the state of the economy, especially inflation and employment. He knows that as well as does anybody else who stops to think about it but the Government has failed totally to create an environment in which there can be a consensus about wage fixation in this country.

In the last six years this Government has quite deliberately gone about promoting policies which display divisive rhetoric and make ineffectual noises about industrial relations issues for quite cynical purposes. A great deal of that is inconsequential and bluster, as we experienced it in regard to the Telecom dispute. As I heard someone say on another occasion, the Minister for Communications, Mr Ian Sinclair, when discussing the attitude of the Government to the Telecom dispute, adopted more positions than one could find in the Kama Sutra. At first he said: 'They won't get a cent out of us.' Then he said that he was going to close Telecom down. Two or three days later he said that he was not going to close Telecom; that there was some justice in the employees' claims. Finally, the Government settled the dispute. What sort of bluster is that? What are the wage earners of Australia to expect from this Government in terms of understanding and trust if such attitudes are displayed by professional loud mouths in the Ministry in the House of Representatives. What sort of standards are those to adopt in approaching industrial relations issues. The ineffectuality of all of this was displayed in figures of the Australian Bureau of Statistics which were reported a few days ago in the Australian Financial Review. The conclusion reached by the survey was:
Intervention by Federal Government officials did not lead to the settlement of one industrial dispute during 1980

The ABS goes on to show how various disputes were settled by negotiation and by reference to the Arbitration Commission. But not one was settled by the bluster of Ministers of this Government. This was again evidenced in relation to the Australian Broadcasting Commission only a few days ago. Of course, there have also been examples of gross mismanagement. If we look at the Telecom Australia and Transport Workers Union disputes, both of which were specifically mentioned by Sir John Moore as a contributing factor to the breakdown of wage indexation, in each case the Government initially opposed the union claims. It invoked the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act against the Telecom employees. It attempted to deregister the TWU.

In connection with the second matter the Prime Minister, in a 43rd floor suite in the Wentworth Hotel in Melbourne, summoned the Labor Premiers of Tasmania and New South Wales to his assistance. The first advice he was given by Mr Wran, the Premier of New South Wales, was this: 'If you want to settle the transport workers' dispute and go to the royal wedding then call off your deregistration application'. That happened. That advice was given to the Prime Minister and he took it. That was after all the bluster in the world about how the Government would get tough with the Transport Workers Union. This sort of action has led to comments by the business community in that the Director of the Employers Federation of New South Wales, Mr Jones, has accused the Government of a sellout in relation to the Transport Workers Union strike.

All those matters are indicative of chronic confusion and mismanagement at a time when this country allegedly faces the prospect of considerable economic growth with no wages policy and no coherent policy on industrial relations. There are no constructive policies coming from this Government on any of those issues. I commend to Government spokesmen on these matters that there are some nettles they have to grasp in relation to these issues. They have to grasp the issues of a prices-incomes policy in this country, the issue of integrity in dealings with employees throughout the community, and the issue of the importance of a centralised wage fixing system. Finally, Government spokesmen have to grasp the nettle of the need for this country to have one uniform system of industrial relations and one uniform system of arbitration rather than the seven systems we now have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech made by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) on the matter of public importance which he put before us concluded really with a plea that we should adopt all the programs and policies of the Australian Labor Party and that that would ensure that the Government had a coherent industrial relations policy. Except in one respect his closing words were in fact a plea for us to adopt not the policies of this Government on which we have gone to so many elections but the policy of the Opposition. There was one point with respect to which the Government is in agreement with him. That is in respect of the importance of a centralised system of wage fixing. The Government's efforts to maintain and sustain a centralised system right up to the present day are, I think, obvious to any impartial observer.

SPEECH.PARA: The case brought by the Opposition seems to be based mainly on the flurry of activity and concern which accompanied the withdrawal of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission from the system of indexation which with some changes has applied since about 1975. Of course, a great deal of concern was expressed by very many sections of the community about what would happen to wages in the light of that withdrawal by the Commission from that system. That was one element of the points put forward by the Leader of the Opposition to support his claim. The other element was to cite records of industrial disputes in a number of countries with which we might most commonly compare ourselves. For example, Canada and the United States are countries which in many respects are like our own. The Leader of the Opposition contrasted those countries with countries such as Austria, Norway, Sweden, Denmark and Germany. He suggested that we need to adopt their policies to achieve the very low levels of industrial strife which he cited in his speech. He also cited for us the low levels of unemployment in those countries, ignoring of course a number of factors, not the least being the quite different social traditions existing in those countries compared with those in the first three he named.

As I understand it, in many of these countries for many years there has been a reliance on migrant workers, a reliance which ceased as their labour was no longer required. Of course, many of those workers have gone back to their places of origin. In fact, there is a whole series of differences between the countries which the honourable senator chose to list.

He very carefully avoided talking about the history of industrial relations in this country and particularly the history of industrial relations during the mid-1970s when we had a government of which he was a supporter. It remains a fact that the highest level of industrial disputation during the decade of the 1970s occurred in 1974, in the middle year of the Whitlam Government. That was a year in which industrial disputation was accompanied by very high increases in wages, both nominal and real. A feature of that year was government leaping into the provision of a series of programs which, according to the speech we heard today, ought to have built a social consensus. Honourable senators will recall the programs put forward in 1974. Virtually everything a man, woman or child could ask for was being promised. The programs were designed and to some extent put into effect. That was in a year when one would have thought there would be maximum social consensus, when real wages were rising rapidly-although inflation was rising it certainly was not rising anywhere near the rate at which wages rose-and when there was government activity of a social type which ought to have been building a great consensus. What did we get? We had the highest level of industrial disputation of the 1970s.

I think we are entitled to be a little chary of the examples put forward by the Leader of the Opposition. I think we are also entitled to be a little chary of his suggestion that the problem of industrial relations in this country is solely a matter of building a consensus on the sorts of policy areas he mentioned in his speech. In fact, the Government is concerned, and has always been concerned since it has been in power, to maintain a coherent industrial relations policy and to reduce the level of industrial disputes. We have never succeeded to the extent that we would have wished.

Let me cite the number of working days lost through industrial disputes for the period 1973-1980 to show that the efforts of this Government have been marked by some successes which might have been envied by the previous Government. In 1973, 2.6 million working days were lost; in 1974, 6.3 million working days were lost; in 1975, 3.5 million working days were lost. In the first year of the Fraser Government the number of working days lost increased on the previous year's figures to a total of 3.8 million. In the following year we lost only 1.7 million working days and in the succeeding year 2.1 million working days. For the next year 4 million working days were lost but the figure dropped back last year to 3.3 million working days.

I cite those figures not to express satisfaction with them. I do not believe any member of the community, let alone any member of the Government, would be satisfied with the level of industrial disputation. I simply cite them to try to put into context the sorts of suggestions made by the Leader of the Opposition and the promises which he held up and which seem so remote from the reality of the performance when these grand social designs were being put forward in 1973-75 to the apparent gross dissatisfaction not merely ultimately of the electorate but indeed of the trade union movement that one would have thought would have been most enamoured of what was being done.

The Government spelt out its objectives in this field when it came to government. We said that we would work to improve the industrial relations climate and to protect the rights of individuals and of the public. How often do we hear the Opposition talking about the rights of individuals and the public in this country to be protected against industrial activity which is to their detriment? Indeed, every time we have sought to legislate to protect individuals against being leaned on by trade union power that legislation has been opposed in this place; it has been seen as inimical to the interests of the trade union movement. I notice that the British trade unions are now challenging the findings of the human rights court in Europe because they too seem to oppose the idea that individuals as well as trade unions should have rights in the community.

We said that we would emphasise the responsibilities of all parties to meet their obligations and that we would improve conciliation and arbitration procedures. I think in all these debates it is important to remember that we as a government do not have directing primary power. Under the Constitution we have a primary obligation to provide a legislative framework for the resolution of industrial disputes. Sometimes it is a matter of frustration in the community, as it is in government, that one cannot simply, by waving a legislative wand or taking some executive act, solve an industrial dispute. In fact, we are primarily responsible for providing a framework within which disputes, when they occur, can be settled.

It is a key part of the Opposition's case today, and an expressed part of the matter of public importance under discussion, that the Fraser Government has moved to exacerbate industrial disputes. A key part of what was said by Senator Button was that we are faced with the problem of the collapse of wage indexation and are now placed in a situation in which we have no industrial relations policy. Yet over the last fortnight the Government has met with the trade union movement, employers and State governments. With each of those bodies it has discussed the necessity of supporting a centralised wage fixing system. It seems that the Government has achieved agreement with all of those bodies that that ought be done.

As I have said, the Government's intention is to establish a framework which not merely goes to the settling of disputes but which also has some of the other objectives which I have mentioned-in particular, the protection of the rights of individuals within the system. We have, as a government, moved in several ways since we took office to protect individuals and the public interest. I wish to mention some of the changes we have made to the industrial relations system to try to achieve our objectives. We established the National Labour Consultative Council to ensure regular consultation at the national level. We legislated to provide secret postal ballots for elections in federal employer and employee organisations. We legislated to require industrial organisations to produce audited annual financial accounts to members. We legislated also to protect genuine conscientious objectors to union membership.

As I list these matters, I am reminded of the number of occasions on which members of the Opposition opposed these pieces of legislation, notwithstanding their apparent importance in protecting the situation of individual unionists and individual Australians. We made various changes to the legislation to improve the procedures of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. We extended the grounds for deregistration of organisations acting in a way which would damage the interests of the community. We strengthened the Commission's powers to deal with demarcation disputes. We established the Industrial Relations Bureau to secure observance of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and regulations and awards. Most recently, and very importantly, we extended the secret ballot provisions to enable individual employees to apply for a secret ballot to express their views on strike action. I think that is the most recent debate which has taken place in this chamber on the subject which is before us this afternoon. Again, I recall that the concept of a group of employees concerned about a strike situation being entitled to apply and to have their views tested in a secret ballot was strenuously opposed in this place by Opposition senators.

The Government legislated also to protect the individual's right to continue to work rather than participate in industrial action. I think that a speaker from the Government side may wish to make some comments later on the value which has been found in that legislation in permitting people to avoid the tyranny of unions and to work in a situation where they wish to provide services for the public. I would have thought that after the last fortnight this was the worst possible time to bring this matter before the Senate. In fact, in the last fortnight the Government has shown a strong commitment to ensuring that there is an orderly process of wage fixation following the cessation of the indexation system.

I have already referred to the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and other senior Ministers, including the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner), have sat down with the trade unions, employers and the State governments. They have sought to ensure that the processes will remain orderly and on foot. I believe the public announcements by the Government over the last couple of weeks, in concert with the State Premiers, and the announcements made by employers clearly indicate an overwhelming adherence to the principles of a central wage fixing system and an adherence to the fact that through the national wage cases the great bulk of wage and salary earners in this country will continue to receive wage justice through the system of conciliation and arbitration established under Commonwealth legislation.

A number of other elements in the arrangements which have been made over recent months indicate the Government's commitment to having an industrial system which does meet the needs of the community and which can be seen to be fair and to serve all sections of the community. Agreement in principle has been reached with the State Premiers-I stress that this includes Premiers from Labor States-on the establishment of a wide-ranging national inquiry into wage determination and industrial relations. I suppose the very fact that the Premiers and the Federal Government see a need for that sort of inquiry does indicate a sense of dissatisfaction at all levels of government. The important thing is that there is an agreement in principle that that dissatisfaction should be worked through by some common approach which might lead to achieving better solutions in this country.

The basic purpose of the proposed inquiry is to achieve a better understanding and a more harmonious climate of industrial relations and to enable the development of a system of wage determination and industrial relations which meets the future needs of the Australian community. Although that decision in principle was made some months ago, the Commonwealth and State Ministers for Labour will be meeting next month to consider the draft terms of reference for the national inquiry into wage determination and industrial relations. That inquiry will not take place in a vacuum. It is an inquiry which the statements of the last few weeks indicate will take place in the context of regular major cases coming before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission with the prospect of a major national wage case taking place either later this year or early in the new year. There is a unified approach to this matter. If there are defects in the system those defects can be tackled on a basis which involves all of the key parties to the matter. The Government holds the view that although wage indexation has come to an end-it has come to an end notwithstanding the Government's attempts to buttress that system-there will be no lapse into a situation of no rules or no law but rather a use of the existing mechanisms which will ensure that an orderly system does continue.

I think that in the minds of members of the public the attitude towards the Federal Government with respect to industrial relations is in a large part influenced not merely by the sort of role of government which was referred to by Senator Button in speaking on the matter of public importance, but also by a quite separate aspect; that is, the role of the Commonwealth not as a government but principally as an employer. I believe public concern about industrial disputation focuses most closely and most harshly on the areas where government itself is supposed to provide services. The widespread concern which is felt in the community when there is a disruption of what is seen as an essential public service is a concern which is shared by government. In that regard the Government brings to its attitude to its own employees the general approach that it expects other parties to bring to industrial relations; that is, it expects the parties to rely on a process of negotiation. Where negotiation fails, after a dispute has been submitted to the processes of arbitration which are available, and if public employees are not prepared to follow those processes of negotiation, it can become necessary for government to take more direct action to protect the public interest. This is a difficult area for government but I believe there is a strong expectation in the community that we will not allow the community to be massively disadvantaged by people who are in public employment and who are, therefore, in a position to hold the community to ransom. In the very difficult area of the Commonwealth dealing with its own employees, the Government takes the view that it must require both itself and its employees, in the main, to rely on the processes of negotiation and arbitration, but the Government must in the end maintain ultimate responsibility, hence the additional powers which it maintains in that area.

I believe it is totally wrong to suggest that there is no coherent Government industrial relations policy. It is certainly wrong to suggest that we have moved in a way which exacerbates industrial disputes. Rather, I think there has been at times a sense in the community that we have done too little, that we have not been firm enough in dealing with industrial disputes which occur. I think that the line which needs to be trodden is a fine one. I believe the Government has conscientiously tried to tread it and in a large part has succeeded in its attempts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to supplement the timely remarks of my leader, Senator Button, about the shambles that exist today in the industrial relations field. I could do no better than to start with a quotation from Mr Justice Kirby at a recent industrial relations seminar, in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: In our search for improved industrial relations, we have concentrated on the trees to the neglect of the forest.

I interpret that as the failure of governments to capture the hearts and minds of the rank and file trade unionists. When I look around this chamber I see my new colleague from South Australia, Senator Foreman, who is a former official of the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia. I think he would agree with me that if members of the vehicle industry were asked how they see their future, they would shake their heads. They wonder from week to week about job security, and that situation has come about because the Government speaks with a forked tongue in relation to its tariff policy. In the clothing and textile industries and in the rubber industry people are wondering what their future is, and consequently they are motivated to maintain wage relativities as far as possible.

Let me take the matter a little further. I take umbrage at the comments of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) about the industrial relations policy of the Australian Labor Party. The plain fact is that all of the Labor Party's proposed legislative innovations in the field of industrial relations, along with those in other spheres, were emasculated by the Senate. Notwithstanding that, it is to the credit of Clyde Cameron that many innovations have been undertaken. It is significant that, in regard to the role of the shop delegate or the shop steward, the creation of the Clyde Cameron College added considerably to the industrial know-how of future trade unionists, not merely stewards but paid officials. When we come to specifics, the average rank and file trade union member today has grave doubts about the technological age in which we live. It would be very hard to prophesy what will happen in five years, much less 10 years, in many industries. No matter what sort of high level deal might be made at the Lodge in Canberra or with a State Premier, the rank and file trade union member is in a situation where he must wonder about his future.

The rank and file unionists today, particularly those under the age of 35, are not overawed by somebody who is supposed to be a legend in the trade union movement. At their meetings now the dialogue goes along different lines. Proposals are put and they discuss a clause and ask what it means. Good negotiators though these representatives may be, they could be somewhat uncertain. Someone will say: 'You had better get that clarified. We will meet again in three days' time.' The person who moves that sort of motion is not indulging in treason. He believes that Jack is as good as his master. In many ways, over the last 15 years, the Press and the Government have developed trade union bosses. Anyone who knows his trade unionism today is well aware that, by and large, the momentum comes from the bottom, and probably it is a good thing that package deals are not accepted automatically.

Let me go on a little further and consider how we operate in these situations. Reference was made by Senator Button in his lucid style to the Scandinavian situation. I know for a fact that about two years ago the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), when he met with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, considered the idea of an in-built stabilising health scheme. It is true that no health scheme is free in the real sense, but in Scandinavia, West Germany, France, and a host of other countries there are not the fluctuations in medical and health coverage that we have with the luxury of a multiplicity of funds. I speak as a member of Medibank Private, but even there I believe it is wrong that a production manager pays the same fees as a process worker. That is one facet of the basic wage compilation. In Europe one can bargain with the state and there is a more uniform health coverage. Nobody will deny that the moment these funds increase their fees again the impact will be felt by the middle and lower income trade union members.

Turning to the composition of wages, it is well known that Bob Hawke, the Labor Party's spokesman on industrial relations, has referred to a two-tier system. I think it will be accepted, and I know my colleague from the west, Senator Gordon McIntosh, a prominent member of the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union, would agree, that once upon a time the fitter was the key figure in the metal trades award. That was the bench-mark, and there were then other developments. Dealing with relativities, and I am referring now to the non-craft union grades, who have a certain parity with the fitter under the metal trades award, the tyre builder in the Federated Rubber and Allied Workers Union of Australia and the car and wagon fitter in the railways are not tradesmen in the sense of having served a five-year apprenticeship. However, due to certain other duties, they have some parity with a tradesman. Once we got away from using the metal trades award as the pacesetter, we had all the confusion that exists today. No trade union official, even if he were an industrial Einstein, could get a perfect settlement, and there is an obligation on the Government to accept this two-tier system. For instance, taking the example of miners working at the coal face and AMWSU member doing maintenance, the danger side of mining has to be guaged. This is too broad a subject to go into in its entirety but, if we operated under the two-tier system, every quarter or every six months cognisance would be taken of fluctuations in food prices and so on, and we could arrive at a base rate. In an industry where new techniques are being introduced which involve some danger, the second tier would apply. To me these things are quite simple, and they are able to be elucidated to the rank and file, but they are non-existent. When Senator Chaney asks what can governments do, I think that is the first nettle the Government should grasp.

Turning to the complexities of this matter, I must be very careful here because I do not want to offend many colleagues of mine in the trade unions who face a very difficult situation. In the containerisation industry, there is declining membership in the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia. The Transport Workers Union of Australia, the Federated Storemen and Packers Union of Australia and the Federated Clerks Union of Australia are also involved. Let me deal with the latter union, and I will be deliberately careful about how I put it. The tally clerks are a component of the Federated Clerks Union, and their conditions are completely different from those of clerks in an air-conditioned office. Probably they have some similarity to clerks in the other two unions I mentioned, but I am not going to take sides. The plain fact is that there is an honest difference of opinion in the port of Sydney between rank and file tally clerks and the Federated Clerks Union management committee about the right to elect vigilance officers, or organisers. For better or worse, they took this matter before a judge, there was a lengthy hearing, and ultimately the judge decided that the matter was not within his jurisdiction. One side would say that the rule is tyrannical, the other side would say that it is the right of the management committee. I am simply saying that it is an indictment of our industrial relations system that nobody is able to solve the problem. That dispute will go on and on. I suppose the feeling of the rank and file is that they are levying themselves to pay for the two vigilance officers to speak for them, and the management committee is very hostile to the idea. The problem has not been solved.

There is an argument between the Australian Workers Union and the WWF over coverage in the wheat industry in Western Australia. So many of these matters are drifting on, and I refer particularly to the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation and the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia. It seems to me that our industrial system could work much more effectively. I do not mean that we have to go after Norm Gallagher with a big stick; far from it. I know that my colleague Mr McBean, of the Trades and Labour Council in Sydney, the AWU and the FIA have had long talks with the BLF, and I know that other building trade unions have differences with that union. Nevertheless, to say that there is no role for the Government in this area is an attitude of cowardly neglect. There is a role for the Government, and I am putting the matter through the eyes of the rank and file trade unionists.

One group of senior Government Ministers have said that tariffs are coming down. Another group have said that they will remain as they are. Senator Chaney referred to the guestworker component in the Western European workforce. What he omitted to say, and this is a problem the Government will have to face this year, is that we are accepting our humanitarian obligations in regard to political refugees. By and large, the physique of these refugees is not on a par with that of the normal migrant, who might go to Mount Isa or somewhere like that. The refugees will go in as process workers to Standard Telephones and Cables Pty Ltd, they will go into light industries such as textiles and clothing, and some sections of the rubber industry. If the Government maintains its high tariffs, as it should, it will accept its component of political refugees. But if it does not maintain those tariffs-some members of the Government believe in lowering tariffs-will it have the courage to protect the existing work force with its high migrant content, or will it say: 'We will phase out the industry?' Those migrants do not have a trade so what will happen to them?

TALK.START.PARA: —You can train them.

—I agree with Senator Chipp but that has never been stated specifically. That is the problem. I want to give credit where it is due. When Ian Macphee was Minister for Productivity I spent one morning with members of the rubber workers' union and him. He made phone calls to all over the place. We were able to get 700 people replaced. But that cannot be done all the time. That was two years ago. Take the situation of an average Australian born person who lives in New South Wales, is 42 years of age, has kids aged 11 and 13 years and is a rubber worker with Dunlop. Say Dunlop moves from New South Wales to Victoria. He might say: 'I will go and live in Victoria'. But he is happy where he is. This has nothing to do with State rivalries. Money is not the issue. That is a difficult situation in a democracy. We cannot order people to move across borders. I am simply trying to sketch a picture of the situation. Those are complexities we ought to be dealing with more effectively and questions to which we ought to be giving answers.

SPEECH.PARA: We could go a little further. I have been a critic of the Industrial Relations Bureau and have questioned why it does not do certain things. I refer honourable senators to Question on Notice No. 866 concerning sexual harassment within industries, largely harassment of females, often from other countries. In the question I referred to the Sydney metropolitan railway system and to allegations concerning women carriage cleaners. I received an answer from the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Chaney) stating that Mr Commissioner Walker was expected to have the findings of an industrial board on 16 July. In fairness, I understand that the Commissioner suffered a bout of illness but the Commission is not moving quickly enough. Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to have a copy of Question on Notice No. 866 and the Minister's answer incorporated in Hansard. I showed it to your colleague, Senator Baume, and I have his approval.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Senator Mulvihill asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 12 June 1981:

(1) What role is the Department of Industrial Relations playing in the investigation of allegations that sexual harassment is applied to female carriage cleaners in the Sydney Metropolitan Railway System.
(2) Which Conciliation Commission has been entrusted with any investigation contemplated into these allegations.

(3) Have any (a) assessors; (b) advisors; or (c) consultants been appointed to assist the Conciliation Commission assigned to this mission: if so, (a) what are the names of such advisors and what are their qualifications, (b) what remuneration will they receive for their services; and (c) what authority will pay such remuneration to them.
(4) Will the proceedings of this inquiry be open to the public and what is the venue.
Senator Chaney-The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) The investigation is being conducted by a Local Industrial Board established under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. The Department of Industrial Relations is not involved in that investigation.

(2) Commissioner Walker of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is entrusted with resolving the dispute. He established a Local Industrial Board pursuant to section 44 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 on 9 April 1981 to assist him in this matter.
(3) (a) The Local Industrial Board comprises:
Ms Suzanne JOBSON, Chairperson
Ms Dorothy BUCKLAND, representative of employees
Mr Harry SHIRLAW, representative of the State Rail Authority of New South Wales
Ms Jobson is a member of the Anti-Discrimination Board of New South Wales
Ms Buckland is a Commissioner of the Ethnic Affairs Commission of New South Wales
Mr Shirlaw is a retired associate manager, industrial section of the State Rail Authority.

(b) The Chairperson is paid a fee of $100 per sitting day by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. If the sitting is for less than three hours in any day, the payment is $50. Payments for fees and expenses to Ms Jobson have totalled $2,677.63 to date.
The other members are, as far as is known, paid by the organisations they represent, but do not receive fees from the Commonwealth Government for their attendances at Board meetings.
(c) See (b).

(4) The Local Industrial Board's proceedings were not open to the public. A report of the Board's findings is due to be presented to Commissioner Walker on 16 July 1981. The course of the dispute and the question of whether the Board's report will be made public will be within the Commissioner's discretion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I go a bit further and refer to a letter dated 16 June 1981 from the then Acting Minister for Industrial Relations, the Honourable W. Fife. I had put a series of questions, one of which related to the exploitation of migrant women in the Wollongong area. Mr Fife said in his letter to me that the matter had been drawn to the attention of the Director of the Industrial Relations Bureau for investigation. That letter was dated 16 June and we are now in the middle of August. It was not such a difficult thing to answer. Why do we not receive answers? If asked whether we are working well enough, I say that we are not. These problems that I mention are not new problems. At the end of the Chifley era about 16 conciliation commissioners were appointed in one bite and they did a very good job. But that conciliation system is not the perfect system any more.

SPEECH.PARA: In the relatively short time at my disposal I advocate a two-tier wage system, permitting greater latitude at the second tier relating to disability allowances and skill, without upsetting wage relativities. We have massive fluctuations in health charges. If we had the European inbuilt system of health charges, it might mean that we pay a bit more income tax in a year but our budgets throughout the year would remain the same. If an employee had a year when he earned extra overtime he would pay a bit more. Under the present system a process worker pays the same as a production manager. This is a source of discontent. It is manifested more among people in the lower grade professions than in the higher grade professions.

I started my speech with the definition of rank and file militancy. I think Senator Lewis made reference to the air traffic controllers in the United States of America. According to Time and Newsweek, most of those air traffic controllers are Republican voters; they are not blue collar Democrat supporters. The same applies in Sydney. Some of the people who have been engaged in disputes, who have tried to protect wage relativities, live in electorates such as the Bradfield electorate; they do not come from militant electorates such as Blaxland and Reid. In supporting the views of Senator Button, I have endeavoured to indicate areas in which the Government could bring in innovations and get the confidence of the rank and file trade unionists. So far it does not have that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating as a matter of public importance the Government's industrial relations policy. Firstly, the principal objectives of the Government's industrial relations policy have been constant since they were expounded in 1975 and they have been repeated frequently. In summary, they are to work to improve the industrial relations climate, to protect the rights of individuals and the public interest, to emphasise the responsibility of all parties to meet their obligations, and to improve conciliation and arbitration procedures. In discussing this subject today, the Opposition speakers seemed to overlook totally the constitutional limitations imposed on the Federal Government. That is a great pity because it must always be remembered, when discussing what the Federal Government can do in relation to its industrial relations policy, that the only power which it has is to legislate in respect of conciliation and arbitration for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes extending beyond the limit of any one State.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat that the Government has power to bring in legislation dealing only with conciliation and arbitration. This Government has no power to bring in a wages and prices policy as put forward by Senator Button who opened this debate for the Opposition. All the Government can do is to pass legislation relating to conciliation and arbitration which is specifically for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes. There has to be an industrial dispute before the Government can apply its legislation. Such a dispute must extend beyond the limit of any one State. That is a very severe limitation on our economic power. Strangely enough, although that is not recognised by Opposition speakers in this place, it is recognised by the shadow Minister for Industrial Relations-I understand his name is Mr Hawke-who as recently as 12 August of this year said in a speech to the Industrial Relations Society:
The Australian Government has less comprehensive and relevant powers of economic management than virtually any other national government in the world.

That must never be forgotten. From time to time there have been attempts to give the Commonwealth Government a power in these matters but on each occasion the people of Australia have rejected those propositions. Our power to take action in this field is severely limited. Having said that, I mention the two areas to which I suggest we should give consideration on this subject. The first area relates to the Government's position as an employer. Notwithstanding the constitutional limitation, the Government has power to pass legislation to control its own employees. I refer not only to direct employees of the Government but also to employees of statutory authorities of the Commonwealth Government. The fundamental principle of the Government's legislation, one that I have already mentioned and one that the Government constantly tries to implement, is to encourage the use of the framework established for the orderly settlement of disputes. That has been the purpose of the Government's legislation all the time. The Government has set out a framework for the orderly settlement of disputes involving its employees and the Government insists that its employees negotiate within that framework.

What in fact happens is that guerilla tactics are adopted from time to time by Government employees. What has this Government done to try to stop those guerilla tactics and to encourage the employees to work within the framework which it established? Firstly, we passed the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act. Having passed this Act, we did not proclaim it at that stage, hoping that the employees would realise that their guerilla tactics would not be tolerated by this Government. But after a certain time, of course, it became obvious that they were not acting within the framework and so, in order to encourage once again the proper settlement of disputes, the Government adopted the common law principle of no work as directed-no pay. That operated for a short time until 1979, when there was a court decision which said that the Government could not apply that common law principle for certain technical reasons which I will not bother to go into.

The Government immediately legislated to cover that situation in order to ensure that it could in fact adopt the principle of no work as directed-no pay. Subsequently, certain Commonwealth employees proceeded to adopt the guerrilla tactic of having one person not work one day, then another person in the department not work the next day and another person in the department not work the following day. As a consequence the Government was unable to persuade its employees in certain areas to go back into the framework for the proper and orderly settlement of their disputes under the existing provisions. So again the Government had to take stronger action to enforce the use of this proper settlement. It proclaimed the CE (EP) Act. That Act was used only once in the years 1979 and 1980. Of course, during the last 12 months Commonwealth employees have more frequently adopted guerrilla tactics and so it has become necessary during 1981 to use the provisions of the CE (EP) Act.

What am I talking about in relation to the CE (EP) Act? The CE (EP) Act enables the Commonwealth Government to suspend people who are taking industrial action and to stand down fellow employees who are unable to work as a result of the industrial action being taken by their colleagues. During 1981 the Government has used this procedure on four occasions. Earlier this year the Australian Telecommunications Commission stood down 1,045 keyboard and clerical staff who were engaged in a dispute over comparative wages. Also, 1,182 striking Commonwealth employees were stood down in relation to a transport workers dispute. In addition, 460 licensed aircraft maintenance engineers were stood down, although some may have been suspended, as recently as earlier this month. Last weekend the Australian Broadcasting Commission suspended some 90 striking broadcast engineering officers.

I suppose one could say that the proof of the pudding is in the eating in relation to the use of this Act by the Government. In fact-I am unable to say precisely whether this has been due to the use of this Act or to other factors-people have gone back to work very shortly after the Government has implemented the provisions of this Act. I do not know whether that is direct cause and effect. In any event there seems to have been a proper result. But what I do say to the Senate is that these measures have not been used to exacerbate the disputes but have been used to discourage guerrilla tactics and to encourage employees to use the due processes of the legislation for the resolution of their disputes. The fundamental principle of the Government is to persuade its employees to use the framework which it has established for the orderly settlement of disputes and not to step outside that framework with guerrilla tactics of strikes and disruption of essential services to the nation in which most employees of the Commonwealth Government are employed. That is the way the Government treats its employees. It is trying to persuade them to use the framework which it has established to settle their disputes.

Looking at the situation in relation to the nation as a whole-in other words, as a government-and remembering the constitutional limitations which I have mentioned and the objectives of the Governent, let us have a look at what this Government has legislated to do. It has legislated to establish the National Labour Consultative Council, to provide secret postal ballots, to require industrial organisations to produce audited annual financial accounts to members, to protect genuine conscientious objectors to union membership, to improve the procedures of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, to extend the grounds for deregistration of organisations acting to damage the interests of the community, to strengthen the Commission's powers to deal with demarcation disputes, to establish the Industrial Relations Bureau, to seek observance of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, regulations and awards, to extend the secret ballot provisions to enable individual employees to apply for a secret ballot to express their view on strike action and, finally, to protect individuals who wish to work when strike action is taken by their colleagues. All this legislation has been passed by this Government in following the fundamental objectives which it laid down as far back as 1975.

What has happened? In recent weeks, of course, indexation has gone. Some people seem to think that the whole situation has fallen into a vacuum because indexation has gone. That is all nonsense. The Conciliation and Arbitration Act runs into some 188 pages. Of course, that Act remains. That Act protects the rights of individuals that I mentioned a few moments ago. It controls unfair industrial practices. It controls union officials and their accounts. The deregistration provisions are all set out there. The legislation exists to provide a framework for the proper negotiation and settlement of disputes without the need for guerrilla action by unionists and, I might say, by some employers. I do not deny the strength of some employers in these matters. But a whole procedure has been established to provide for the proper negotiation and settlement of disputes, and that continues notwithstanding the abandonment of indexation. Certainly the Government's industrial relations policy still exists. This policy not only exists but will also be enforced. Certain pieces of legislation which the Government has introduced, and which I have mentioned, are designed to ensure that the people of Australia endeavour to settle their industrial disputes properly.

In the few minutes remaining to me I would like to point out that the protection has been established. We trust that the parties will be encouraged to use the Commission and that within that framework industrial disputes can be settled. Certainly the Government should intervene in industrial disputes where the public interest requires it. The national wage case is a perfect example. But, with all due respect, I do not see any reason for the Government to get its cotton-picking fingers into every industrial disputation in this country, notwithstanding the media constantly running to the Government and saying 'What are you going to do?' when someone is going out on some small strike about something or other. The legislation is there to enable the parties to settle their dispute. It is there to enable the unionists to enforce their rights; it is there to enable employers to enforce their rights. I do not see that the Government should be interfering or intervening in every dispute between employers and employees. As a matter of fact, I think that the less frequently the Government intervenes in these matters the more there will be rapid settlement of disputes. So I say to the Senate that the Government's industrial relations policy is an excellent policy, it is well enforced by the legislation within the constitutional limitations and it is a matter for praise by the public of Australia.
