TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling Senator Siddons I remind the Senate that this is his maiden speech and I ask honourable senators to extend to him the usual courtesies extended to anybody making his first speech in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I first wish to refer to the honour conferred on me by the people of the State of Victoria and the appreciation I have of the function of the Senate as a States assembly and a House of review. I hope that the Senate has gained greater flexibility to act as a true House of review in the future. In industry we have a saying when a young executive is subjected to a lot of pressure. We say that he has had a baptism of fire. I cannot escape the feeling that this has happened to me over the last two days.

SPEECH.PARA: Moving from confrontation to co-operation in industrial relations is vital if this country is to solve the very real problems that lie ahead. There are many problems with Australia's industrial relations legislation. We have overlapping Federal and State awards. We have too many unions and employer organisations. We have demarcation disputes, leapfrogging. We have direct negotiations by unions on logs of claims which lead to temporary solutions but do not result in any written contract for a period of industrial peace between unions and management. Australia's industrial relations legislation is in rapid need of overhaul.

The most fundamental problem facing Australia's industrial relations today, however, is not the legislation but the humanisation of the work place. Unless we can find an organisation structure that allows people to use their human qualities of imagination, initiative, technical expertise and sociability continued strife is inevitable. Nothing can compensate people for eight hours frustrating, monotonous, mind-killing work. If we are to be honest with our children we have to offer them something better than saying that if they work hard they will be able to work their way up a rigid hierarchy. It was Anthony Jay in his magnificent book Management and Machiavelli who outlined the family tree that most people have firmly in their minds. It went something like this: There is a head of a company and he has three people reporting to him. Those three people in turn have three people reporting to them and it goes on down to the seventh line by which time there are 278 junior managers and an urgent need for a large triangular piece of paper. We have to offer our children something better than that.

There is no simple solution to how we can achieve the humanisation of the work place but there are five basic principles that, if adopted, could lead to a work environment that allows people to use their abilities to a much greater degree than most industries are able to allow today. The first of these five principles is a cellular organisational structure. This involves dividing the organisational structure into small autonomous groups of about 40 people and allowing each group to have the ability to manage its work, to hire and fire people, to plan for the future, to work its own overtime and to be self-managing and self-directing. To do this there has to be a profit system which shows the members of that group how they are performing each month against the budget and allow them scope to affect their own improvements to what they are doing.

The second basic principle is profit-sharing. If people are to work in small autonomous groups and if those people know what profits are being generated, it is only right that they should have a means of sharing in the profits. Profit-sharing should be based on profits before tax in relation to the assets employed in the organisation. The third principle is an open organisational structure in which there are no secrets about profits and sales. This can be achieved through a consultative council made up of workers and management represenatives, with the worker representatives appointed by a secret ballot. Apart from getting information on how the company is performing this consultative council should also have power to pass resolutions directly on working conditions relating to safety and so forth. Such a consultative council should not have power over wages and award rates which is the rightful province of the trade union movement.

The fourth principle is flexible working hours. I believe the time has long past when we should be directing our attention to an eight-hour working day. We have to have a much more flexible approach to working hours. For a start, an eight-hour day does not suit most women in the work force. They are confronted with a decision to work and neglect their families or not to work at all. Many young people would prefer to work more than eight hours. So we believe a more flexible arrangement is vital. My fifth and final point relates to the sharing of ownership by employees. The interests of capital and labour are very much easier to reconcile if, to some degree, the employee has a vested interest in the company in which he works. The sharing of ownership by employees breaks down the separation between the interests of labour and capital.
We have to move towards these five principles if we are to seek co-operation in industry. Their application has to be worked out for each specific company.

What is the wage fixing policy of the Australian Democrats? We believe the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission ought to continue to fix minimum wages and conditions and minimum awards for skill and resolve demarcation disputes. However, in future over-award payments and improvements in conditions ought to be negotiated directly by shop stewards and factory management on a factory by factory basis. The people who know most about the dispute should be the ones to be involved in the direct negotiations. Shop stewards could call in their unions on a consultative basis in the same way as management uses industrial relations consultants. The actual negotiating would best be done by managers and representatives directly. Such agreements, once arrived at, would have much greater likelihood of being honoured because the parties would have been negotiating directly rather than negotiating through a third party. The agreements ought to be put in writing and should be binding for a period of 12 months.

Such an agreement would free employers from the worry of having constant disputes, yet they could grant better pay and conditions to employees on the basis of market forces and local conditions. Such contracts could be enforced by the Australian Industrial Court and could provide for fines if parties broke the agreement, as is the case in the United States of America and in most European countries. The contract could include a clause providing that no internal claims or work stoppages for wages and conditions would be made during the lifetime of the agreement. Any domestic situation that developed which might lead to a conflict or have the potential of leading to a conflict could be resolved by a request by either party for a meeting to take place within 24 hours, and during that 24 hours work should continue.

The present situation is intolerable for both unions and employers. Unions can present several logs of claims a year. Employers must have a period of industrial peace but equally unions have every reason to try to preserve the standard of living of their members. No system, no matter how enlightened, can maximise human potential unless it humanises the work place. I intend to present to this Parliament a Bill to provide incentives for employers to introduce industrial democracy. Such a Bill will not pass this Parliament without the support of both parties and I appeal to all honourable senators and members to pass such a Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I would like first to congratulate you on your election to the highest office in this Parliament. I am sure that you will enjoy your term as President and I look forward to working under you. I would also like to congratulate Senator Siddons on his maiden speech. It was very thought provoking. The matter of public importance before the Senate refers to 'the exacerbation of industrial disputes by the Fraser Government'. That has a very familiar ring. Every one of us has heard that sort of thing a thousand times. Every time the Government takes any stand at all we hear from the Opposition benches and from the militant trade union section the same old thing-'Government confrontation'. We never hear of union confrontation; it is always Government confrontation.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer now to Australia's present position. In July-last month-we were presented with an Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development forecast and leading articles in the newspapers made reference to this. The Australian Financial Review ran an article which was headed 'It's good news week for Fraser. Australia leads Western growth stakes'. The article stated:
Australia stands to enjoy the highest economic growth rate among developed Western nations over the next 18 months, according to the OECD's latest world economic outlook.

We find that unemployment is expected to go down from 6 per cent in 1980 to 4.5 per cent in 1982. The OECD claims that the growth rate in Australia will go from 2.8 per cent in 1980 to 5.75 per cent in 1981 and 5.25 per cent in 1982 while the average of the OECD countries is forecast to be a rise of one per cent for 1981 and 2 per cent for 1982. We will have a rise of 5.75 per cent and the OECD average is expected to rise by one per cent. Private investment in Australia has gone from 4.3 per cent in 1980 to 9 per cent in 1981. Whilst we have a trade deficit this year, in 1982 we expect exports to exceed imports.

The only cloud on the horizon concerns the consumer price index. Bearing in mind that if none of our policies is to be altered, the forecast is that Australia's CPI will go from 10.2 per cent in 1980 down to 9.5 per cent in 1981 but then will rise to 11.25 per cent, so the OECD claims, in 1982. The average for other OECD countries is going down. It went from 11.3 per cent in 1980, which was well over our figure, to 10 per cent in 1981. Again that is over our figure, but that average is going down whereas our figure is going up. According to the OECD forecast, the average for other countries in 1982 will be 9 per cent.With that forecast one would think that all Australians, from all walks of life, would work to demolish that one cloud, the increase in the CPI. One would think that all Australians would work towards lowering the consumer price index and then, having done that, would work towards reducing the unemployment figure-the 1982 forecast for which is 4 1/2 per cent-even further. In that way we could reach the prosperity in this country that we had under the Menzies Government.

Instead of that, what do we have? As soon as the good news was forecast we had two of the worst strikes one could imagine. Perhaps the two unions involved-the Waterside Workers Federation and the Transport Workers Union-thought that was the best way to destroy that good news. They certainly worked towards the gathering of that one dark cloud on our horizon. Mr Martin Cooper, the secretary of the TWU in Tasmania, came out with an extraordinary statement. The article in which his statement was reported reads:
. . . another transport strike would be more severe on Tasmania than the two-week stoppage last month.

Imagine any Tasmanian at all saying: 'Don't worry, we can do more damage to Tasmania than we did last month. Try us and we will do ever so much more'. Tasmania lost $12m, on a conservative estimate, through that strike. We have been assured by the State secretary of the Transport Workers Union that that is chicken feed and that the transport workers can do much more damage to the State. Newspapers in Australia such as the Age have seen the need to put out a strike casualty rate column each day saying that, for example, we cannot get milk in most shops today; the wharves are all closed and we have $80m worth of cargo still tied up; government services are disrupted; mail is almost stopped; fuel supplies and plane services are threatened; telephone disruptions are occurring; there is trouble with bread supplies; there has been panic buying of groceries; meat supplies are still lasting but they are not likely to be available on Monday-but beer is all right, we still have beer. It has been reported that thousands are taking leave to avoid standowns. It is an absolutely incredible position. Yet we have the State secretary of the Transport Workers Union saying that the unionists can do more than that; that that is just chicken feed.

I have already mentioned the cost in dollars to Tasmania; I now refer to the rest of the country. According to one estimate in the Australian, at one stage goods worth nearly $200m were tied up at the wharves. It has been called the worst dispute on the wharves and has involved the worst industrial relations on any wharves in the world. We have the cost to the country of a worsening reputation. A mission from Japan came to look at the industrial relations situation because the Japanese could not imagine that it was as bad as they had heard. The export of live sheep is now threatened. There were meant to be record live sheep exports this year of 5.5 million sheep. As soon as that figure was understood to be a record, we had Mr Jack O'Toole saying: 'We'll fix that'. It is an incredible situation.

I wish to refer to the Government's responsibility in this area. We believe we have worked to improve industrial relations. We established the National Labour Consultative Council which comprise of union, employer and government representatives. It is consulted before any industrial legislation is brought into this Parliament. It should work and, indeed, on many occasions it has. We have also established the Industrial Relations Bureau to carry out the decisions of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. We have protected the rights of individuals and provided secret ballots for election to the federal bodies. We have required industrial organisations to produce audited annual financial accounts. We have protected the genuine conscientious objector if he has not wanted to join a union. We have protected the rights of anyone who has not wanted to go on strike. Indeed, we have passed legislation prohibiting unions taking any intimidatory action against people who say: 'I want to work'. Australians have said that men have a right to go on strike, but they have also got in their legislation the right to work. If a man wants to work and does not want to go on strike, we have legislation to protect him. Not only can the unions not intimidate him but also they cannot intimidate his boss and say to the boss: 'You have to get your men out'.

During the last Transport Workers Union strike in Tasmania all the men employed by the private bus owners wanted to work. Every one of those private bus owners had their men working and the buses were not stopped. This enabled tourists to keep travelling around Tasmania. It also enabled all the school children in outlying areas to be taken to school each day. The unions think that is a terrible crime. I can assure honourable senators that that is what they think because one of the other union members said: 'We have learnt a lot. We know how to deal with those people the next time and we will not have strike breakers'. The unions say that it is a disgrace that the bus proprietors and their employees who wanted to work were permitted to take the school children to their schools and to take tourists around our State.

The Government has also worked to emphasise the responsibility of all parties to meet their obligations. That has been done by extending the grounds for deregistration of organisations which act to damage the interests of the community as a whole and also where unions put the health and safety of the community at risk. We have also worked to improve the conciliation and arbitration procedures by broadening the area of concern of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Premiers, the Australian Council of Trade Union leaders, the employers, the employer representatives and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) have all got together to see whether they can do something about industrial relations. Statements have come from these groups. They are all very concerned and they all say that they agree we already have a wages policy and a wages system that ought to be abided by.

The only people who at this moment seem not keen to work together or to co-operate are the members of the Opposition. They have underlined this by bringing this matter of public importance on today. I believe that the Opposition ought to take notice of its erstwhile senator, Senator Wheeldon, who was quoted in the Canberra Times of 17 August as having said:
The fundamental organisational problem of the ALP is the continuation of affiliation of trade unions.

The control which unions have over the party made it very difficult to develop policies for the good of the nation and community as a whole, . . . they were sometimes contrary to policies which favoured trade unions.
By having unions, but not other interest groups, as affiliates, the party was clearly identified as representing only one section of the community.

It is time that we Australians all learnt to pull together. We have a wonderful country; we have so much. Not one of us is independent. Every one of us relies heavily on the other. In my profession as a nurse prior to my coming here, where would I or the patients have been without the cleaners, without the doctors or without the technicians? It is time Australians learnt to pull together. We need each other. Every man needs his neighbour to be responsible. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the the paper.

In doing so I wish to make some fairly brief remarks. I understand that this is the first report of the Film Censorship Board to be tabled. That fact is to be very much welcomed. The Film Censorship Board, which has existed in its present form since 1973, operates under a quite extraordinary miscellany of Federal and State legislative and regulatory provisions. By and large nowadays it does have a completely uniform mode of operation over all the States and over both films shown in cinemas and films shown on television. The exception in this respect is the State of Queensland, which here, as in so many other contexts, insists upon doing its own thing. It has so insisted since 1974. That is not a phenomenon entirely to be regretted, I might add, particularly in the context of film censorship, because it ensures that a rather higher level of civilisation prevails elsewhere in the country as a result of Queensland opting out of the system of uniform censorship that has thus evolved. The other area of exception from the jurisdiction-if I might describe it as such-of the Board, insofar as television films are concerned, appears to be the Special Broadcasting Service, Channel 0/28. The unwillingness of that authority to submit to the jurisdiction of the Film Censorship Board is, I notice, the subject of some adverse criticism in the terms of this report. Maybe that is a matter which requires closer examination as to the desirability or otherwise of Channel 0/28 remaining outside the system.

The basic task of the Film Censorship Board is either to accept or to reject films as being available for screening in cinemas or as viewing on television channels and to classify those films which survive the basic threshold hurdle into one or other of four categories. Those are: G for general exhibition category; the NRC category, not recommended for children under 12 years; the M category for mature audiences; and the R or restricted category whereby persons between the ages of two and 18 are not to be admitted to the cinema. In addition, the Board from time to time allows special conditions to apply to films. This has particularly occurred in the past in relation to films imported for film festivals or for special screenings, for example, at the National Film Theatre of Australia. The exercise of the Film Censorship Board's functions over the years, and in particular over the last year or so, is the subject of some quite fascinating statistical tables in this report. Some very interesting trends have shown up over the years, notably a significant decline in the period since at least 1976-which is the subject of specific statistics-in the number or proportion of films that are actually rejected outright, which has fallen from 5.4 per cent in 1976 to 2.3 per cent in 1980.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it we who are changing, or the films?

—The explanations are interesting in themselves. What might be at stake here is not only an increasing liberalism in the attitude of the Board, or on the part of the community, which the Board is endeavouring to reflect, but also the consideration, which is noted in the report, that there has been a somewhat decreasing patronage of theatres which show R rated erotic material in those States where there is easy access to hard core pornographic films and tapes in adult theatres and sex shops, the adult theatres in question tending to operate, whether within the law or not, rather outside of the censorship system. There is also an increasing availability, for better or worse, of pornography in the form of video cassettes. So, to a considerable extent, the men with gaberdine overcoats need not don them any more but can enjoy the material in question in the privacy of their lounge rooms. Whether that presents a satisfactory alternative to the joy that is otherwise derived from descending those scruffy stairs into dank basements in our various cities remains to be determined.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to those films that are rejected, the trends over the years are interesting to note. Whereas rejection on the ground of sex-one might say straight sex-demonstrates a considerably downward trend, rejection for reasons of violence, or more particularly, combinations of sex and violence, represents a significant upward trend. A number of other things-I do not propose to describe them in detail-might be said about the trends which have emerged with respect to films with G, NRC and M classifications and the kinds of cuts that have been requested regularly by the Censorship Board. One factor in regard to cuts or eliminations that I do pause to note briefly is mentioned at page 13 of the report. Whereas in previous years sex accounted for the majority of eliminations, in 1980 violence and animal cruelty also figured prominently. It must be said that the performance of the Censorship Board has been, at least until quite recently, apparently the subject of universal acceptance, if not actual positive acclaim. Indeed, this much emerges from the report at page 20, where we find described the number of complaints which the Board has received from the community at large. It is there noted that in calendar year 1980 the Board received 67 letters and several telephone complaints, so described, criticising its treatment of theatrical films. The Board notes:

Considering that the complaints were confined to six or seven titles out of a total of 1,050 features registered by the Board in 1980, it would seem that its decisions have met with general acceptance in the Australian community.

Indeed, I endorse that self-description by the Board of what it has been about, and of the way in which, by and large, its performance in recent years seems to have been very much in accord with the increasingly liberal standards in these matters that have become accepted by the community at large.

However, there is one slightly jarring note that I think it proper to intrude. It is perhaps the major reason why I rose to speak on this report. It seems that the Board is starting to take a somewhat harder line towards the category of foreign films that are imported for special purposes, either film festivals or screenings by organisations such as the National Film Theatre. A particular feature of the Board's functions and performance in this respect which has received some recent notoriety is its rejection of a film by the very famous and brilliant Japanese director, Nagisa Oshima, entitled In the Realm of the Senses, which was, in fact, screened quite uncut at the Melbourne Film Festival in 1977 before, I gather, a very large audience-not including myself so I cannot speak with any confidence as to its precise details. It was not allowed by the Board to be imported or screened, without substantial cuts, as part of a retrospective screening of some 14 films by Oshima organised recently by the Australian Film Institute. The Institute, in presenting its retrospective program of Oshima films at the National Film Theatre, quite properly refused to have anything to do with the screening, in the presence of Oshima, of a distorted or mutilated version of the film in question.

This might be regarded as being something of an isolated instance, except that one cannot help noting that Mrs Janet Strickland, the Chairman of the Board, who seems to have been getting a good deal of publicity lately because of her views about the Board and its role in the community-most extensively in the Age of 18 August-acknowledges a change in attitude, if you like a hardening of attitude, by the Board in respect of festival films or films that hitherto have been regarded as being in a special category. She is quoted in the article in the Age as making that point quite vigorously in these words:

I don't personally believe that film festivals should be able to show films that other sectors of the adult population can't see. You can't have one class of adults being exempt from the law. It is elitist to say otherwise. It has no substance in law and no substance in my philosophy.

Although that is certainly a debatable point of view, and as a good socialist I become very sensitive whenever allegations of elitism are thrown about in respect of anyone who argues for a greater degree of liberality, perhaps, in the censorship of certain classes of films in certain contexts, a sensible argument can be made for framing substantially more liberally the censorship standards that are to apply to films of unquestionably high artistic merit and reputation that are imported, or sought to be screened, for purposes such as film festivals and retrospective showings under the auspices of such bodies as the Australian Film Institute. Mrs Strickland seems to have taken a very hard line position, and one that I doubt on the whole would be accepted by most people in the community. I am not even sure-this is the last point that I wish to make-that it is in accordance with the actual philosophy of the Censorship Board, as articulated on pages 3 and 4 of its report. The Board, speaking of its role, states:

Within the limits of the legislation, the Board tries to implement a censorship policy based on the philosophy (shared by the major political parties) that adults have the right to make their own decisions regarding the material they read, hear or see; but that people generally should be protected from exposure to material that may be offensive-or, in the case of children, harmful to them.

If the philosophy is that adult persons should have the right to make their own decisions about what they see, that the only essential restriction to be imposed is that persons generally should be protected from exposure to material that may be offensive-a philosophy that appears to be accepted by the major political parties-something must surely be said for allowing persons who voluntarily make the effort to attend special screenings of films, knowing precisely what kind of film they are about to see, and who are generally literate so far as film culture is concerned, so to do.

There can be no question under those circumstances of a person wandering unaware into a cinema, misled by the kind of advertising that might be outside and being, as a result, offended by extremely graphic scenes with which they might then be confronted. It is very difficult to argue that in those circumstances anyone would be other than a voluntarily, actively consenting, willing participant in the cultural feast or famine, as the case may be, that the film in question actually represents.

I believe, and it is not an unimportant point, that we have mercifully survived for the last 15 or 20 years now without rending discussions or debates in the community about censorship issues. It is a wholly civilised turn of events for Australia that over the last 15 years this has been so. I would regret any suggestion that, as part of the emerging moral conservatism that seems evident in some other familiar cultures, if not yet entirely in our own, there should be a swing back of this particular pendulum. I am not sure, from what is in this report, that the Censorship Board is in fact foreshadowing any major across-the-board swing back of the pendulum towards a more restrictive approach, or view of the world. But in the matter of especially sensitive films, in the special context of film festivals and so on, there does seem to be evidence between the lines of this report, and more specifically in various recent pronouncements by Board members, of an emerging, quite significant, change of heart. If that were I would find it most regrettable, and I would hope that other honourable senators would find it equally so. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF THE PRIME MINISTER AND CABINET

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I want to comment briefly on the somewhat lurid report of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, though I refer to the colour of the report more than the contents. I do so because the report does not correctly describe how the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet intrudes on every other department of the Commonwealth Public Service. Rather than my saying it, I will refer briefly to the words of the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) who explained it all with great clarity and on the basis of lengthy experience on 28 April this year. When talking about the relationship between the Fraser Cabinet and the Parliament he said that our present system has deteriorated because that relationship has foundered. He said:

It has foundered because the Prime Minister increasingly centralised power around himself. Any erosion of the Cabinet system goes to the heart of the parliamentary process. By reposing too much power in the Prime Minister, the system of collective responsibility within Cabinet is destroyed: The responsibility of Cabinet to Parliament is abandoned; and the very democratic process is placed in jeopardy.

The honourable member for Kooyong went on to talk about the handling of the Cabinet by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), which I will not go into here. I am sure there are honourable senators in this place who have a more vivid recollection of that process and a better knowledge of it than I, although they are not in the chamber at the moment. Mr Peacock in his speech of 28 April dealt with the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the subject of this report, in these terms:

Outside Cabinet there is another development, that of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. Apart from the complex system surrounding Cabinet, the House should note that each Commonwealth department is now duplicated in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. This causes waste but, far worse than that, it brings interference with, indeed supervision of, decisions made by Ministers and their departments. The role now given to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet challenges the authority given Ministers under section 64 of the Constitution. There is another equally undesirable effect. It places deep strains on the Public Service because it sets public servant against public servant. It is a major power structure for the Prime Minister. As a consequence, it is at odds not merely with the Constitution but with efficient management of the country.
That is a point that I intend to illustrate in a minute. Mr Peacock continued:

Furthermore, to me, as a Liberal, it strikes at the root of liberalism itself. Liberalism distrusts concentration of power. It has always been associated with checks and balances and the division of powers. Liberals believe that in a healthy society power and decision-making are widely dispersed throughout the community. I see Senator Messner blanch at that thought. Mr Peacock went on:

Mr Speaker, Liberals believe in consensus, and consensus does not mean abject compromise. Strength does not mean bullying. I believe the growth of centralised power within our Government today is restricting effective formulation of policies required by Australia.

The complaint of the honourable member for Kooyong against this Government was that the Prime Minister had a dangerous determination to centralise power. For example, 30 colleges of advanced education are to be rationalised; the college in Mr Fraser's electorate remains unscathed. General cuts are to be made in defence expenditure, especially defence matters related to research and development. But the Casey University, the Prime Minister's pet idea since 1970, is to remain untouched, at a cost of a minimum of $80m.

These are evidence of what is going on inside the Cabinet in terms of decisions of government which in the words of the honourable member for Kooyong are overborne by the structure of government and the centralisation of power in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and in the hands of the Prime Minister. The report of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet gives further evidence of the hypocrisy of this Government and the hypocrisy of the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I do not think that the last phrase of the honourable senator concerning the hypocrisy of the Prime Minister is appropriate or in accordance with the Standing Orders.
—Senator Button, I ask you to phrase your words in a manner that will not upset the Minister.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I did that. If Senator Baume is alleging that those words are unparliamentary I would like him to substantiate it.
—I seek a ruling from the Chair.
—Order! I do not find that that word is unparliamentary. If the Minister finds himself sensitive to it he should ask for it to be withdrawn.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I will let the matter pass.

—If Senator Baume wants me to say that the Prime Minister says one thing and does another I can document that over about an hour. But I am referring to the hypocrisy of the Government and the hypocrisy of the Prime Minister in relation to the matters already adverted to. I will refer to some other matters. While the Prime Minister has been constantly calling for a reduction in the size of government departments and for general restraint the central organs of Mr Fraser's Government have grown significantly-none more than Mr Fraser's own Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the staff of which has grown by over 17 per cent during his tenure. In spite of the urgings for a reduction in the size of the Commonwealth Public Service and for a reduction in the size of other government departments the staff of the Treasury has grown by 10 per cent, and the staff of the Public Service Board has grown by 5 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Expenditure on the Australian Federal Police Force and security related matters has increased under the Fraser Government by 40 per cent. This is in spite of calls for reductions in Commonwealth expenditure and Commonwealth functions. The report of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet further underlines this trend. In an atmosphere of financial stringency the report discloses that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet spent 15 per cent more in money terms than in 1979-80. That is a growth in real expenditure of about 5 per cent over just one year in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. It represents an acceleration of an already established trend. A look at the Budget forecast indicates that that trend will accelerate further. Money growth in expenditure in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet for 1981-82 is expected to be 23 per cent. What other area has been budgeted for an increase in expenditure of the order of 23 per cent by the Fraser Government at a time when the Prime Minister persistently maintains that the size of the Public Service must be reduced, that the functions of national government must be reduced and that the costs of national government must be reduced? These double standards amount to classic examples and illustrations of the proper use of the word 'hypocrisy' to which I referred to a moment ago. There is real growth of well over 10 per cent in the expenditure of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

It is very nice to have an annual report tabled here with photographs of former Prime Ministers of Australia on the front and back. It is very nice to be assured that members of that Department continue to do the good job which I am sure they do. It is not what is in reports that is important; it is what is left out of them that should be considered from time to time by this Parliament. It is those matters which on 28 April this year the honourable member for Kooyong was constrained to draw to the attention of parliamentarians on both sides, the growth and centralisation of power in the Prime Minister's Department and the adverse effects it was having on the process of democratic parliamentary government in this country. I commend a reading of the report to honourable senators but I commend to their consideration some other matters which are not included in the report. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report of the Royal Military College at Duntroon is a report of an institution which is now drawing to a close. It marks the end of a period or chapter of proud history for that institution. At the whim of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) it has become a place where army cadets in future will get shortened periods of military training. It is to be replaced-I said something like this a few minutes ago-by the Prime Minister's pet project, the Australian Defence Force Academy. At a time when the Australian community is told to exercise restraint, when the ordinary Australian is being slugged with higher taxes-now even a tax on information in terms of books, magazines and newspapers-this utterly wasteful project is to go ahead. This is a story of the Prime Minister's pigheadedness and of what the honourable member for Kooyong, Mr Peacock, has described as the Prime Minister's manic determination to get his own way-Mr Peacock's words, not mine. Mr Fraser, as Minister for Defence, in 1970 first floated this project. It was rejected by the Gorton Government. The following year he participated to some extent in bringing down Mr Gorton as Prime Minister of Australia.

The parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, which is a joint party committee, examined the proposal in some detail, as it was incumbent on that Committee to do, the subject matter having been referred to it. The report of that Committee effectively said that the Committee could see no merit in the proposal educationally, in defence terms or in any other way which would justify the level of expenditure proposed. The level of expenditure proposed is significant. It was announced in December 1979 as being $65m. Four months later the cost of the Casey military university had gone up to $80m. It is now probably closer to $100m. It could be well above that figure by the time it is finished. Quite apart from the reports of the parliamentary Committee and the opposition of that Committee to it, there are other reasons why it is a senseless project. I refer to views held by Australian educational bodies such as the Australian University Vice-Chancellors Committee, the Federation of College Academics and so on. Each organisation has said that the project is wrong in terms of educational priorities to segregate military cadets in an exclusively military environment for university training. Last year the Western Australian Minister for Education, Mr Jones, described it as 'one of the more incredible decisions of the Federal Government'. He was making that criticism on the grounds of educational priority, amongst others.

The proposal to proceed with this so-called university is wrong in terms of defence priorities. Despite the increase vote for defence in last night's Budget, the Government is still hundreds of millions of dollars behind the target figure for defence expenditure set in its own defence White Paper in 1976. The money which is to be spent on this institution could have been better spent in terms of current needs of the Australian military forces on ammunition, such as bullets for the Army, increasing the strength of the Royal Australian Air Force, or allowing pilots to get more flying hours. Any of those things could have been done but they have not been done. By any standards the services are in a pretty shocking state. They are in an abysmal state considering the proposals set out in the Government's own White Paper in 1976 for defence expenditure. The fact is that our defence forces would be incapable of sustaining a defensive effort of any worthwhile size or length of time.

In 1978 the Australian Naval Institute described the academy-this successor to the Royal Military College of Australia, which is the subject of this report-as a 'recipe for disaster'. Officer after officer gave evidence to the Public Works Committee saying that the proposal was undesirable in military terms. The officers included Major-General Vincent, Brigadier Greville, Brigadier Taylor, Air Vice-Marshal Candy and Air Vice-Marshal McNamara. The defence forces of countries such as the United States of America and Britain have never looked at a proposal for a joint academy of this kind. A careful investigation by the Public Works Committee of the Parliament resoundingly opposed the proposal. The decision was unanimous. The Chairman of the Committee, Mr Mel Bungey, a Liberal member, said on the Australian Broadcasting Commission program AM:
We believe the concept is wrong and I certainly won't be supporting anything which I think is wrong.

The Royal Military College at Duntroon, the subject of this report, has served this country well, as has the Royal Australian Naval College and the Royal Australian Air Force college. These institutions are virtually to disappear for no productive purpose. They are to disappear simply to pander to the wishes of the Prime Minister and to ride roughshod over the commonsense view of defence and educational experts and a unanimous decision of the Committee of the Parliament. This is wasted expenditure in the light of consistent calls for constraint in Government expenditure. It is expenditure which is accorded in the light of the priorities to which I have referred in dealing with the report of the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet. I draw these matters to the attention of the Senate because again they concern a question of political priorities with which this chamber has to deal and which we cannot fail to confront in relation to all matters which come before us. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Haines) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act relating to sickness and hospital benefits to provide for a voluntary contribution scheme for health insurance.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide a voluntary contribution scheme as an alternative to private health insurance so that contributions to that scheme are proportionate to the gross income of contributors and so that the beneficiaries are persons whose income is such that they will pay less under the scheme than they would pay for private insurance. Basically, it is a Bill to end an anomaly and an injustice which originated when the present Government last amended existing health insurance schemes. The anomaly I am referring to is the one involving the absolute cut-off line between those people defined by the Government as disadvantaged, and therefore qualifying for free health care, and those who are not so defined. As my colleague, Senator Mason, pointed out during the passage of the enabling legislation last May, this produced the absurd and, in some cases, tragic situation in which, for example, a family with two children whose income was $199 a week was actually better off than that same family would be if its income rose to $205 a week, even allowing for the tax concession available on the health insurance paid in the latter case. This could put millions of Australian children at risk since some parents would be forced not to take health insurance, simply because they could not afford to do so.

It is the intention of the Australian Democrats to correct this anomaly by introducing provisions for the operation of a sliding scale scheme. The purpose of this Bill is to achieve that end in the simplest, least arithmetically or administratively complex way-through the option of a voluntary contribution scheme which is conducted through a levy on gross income until the level of the contribution reaches the level of the cost of basic private health insurance minus the tax concession. It would ensure that a voluntary contributor had the same rights as a disadvantaged person has under the present Act, but would make no provision for hospital only insurance. It is not, of course, restricted to those people whose incomes lie between the present cut-off point and the top end of the sliding scale, as the secondary purpose of this Bill is to provide some element of choice to Australian health insurees. At the moment, they are faced with a very limited one: Not to insure at all and suffer the consequences, or to insure privately with one of a series of companies offering essentially the same product.

Before going on to give details of the way in which the system will work, I would like to comment on the drafting of this and other Bills being introduced by Australian Democrat senators. In the very early stages of our existence as senators, we approached the Parliamentary Counsel for assistance in preparing what were, we knew, some interestingly complex private senators' Bills; complex, that is, for lay people conversant with neither lawyers' English nor drafting procedures. Unfortunately, none was forthcoming. While the Counsel was prepared to spend some considerable time delineating the reasons why he could not help, he was not able to spend any time at all apparently in sorting out any of the problems for which he envisaged we were heading. Indeed, I found his letter to me rather more patronising than was warranted, although this may have been merely an expression of the attitude most lawyers seem to have of lay people rather than any expression of condescension he, as a public servant, had for me, as a mere member of parliament. We turned, therefore, to the Senate staff for help and these Bills are the result.

Much of what we hoped to do must be done by regulation, partly because the figures, incomes and rates concerned are likely to be affected by inflation and are therefore best left out of the actual legislation, and partly because incorporation of them would have made the drafting process and the resultant Bills so much more complex. I mention this point not because I believe that the Parliamentary Counsel was being deliberately obstructionist, but to provide you, Mr President, and honourable senators with the reason for the fact that much of the 'meat' of the Bill is to be enshrined in regulations.

I must also point out that in the event of this Bill passing both Houses-a highly unlikely event at the best of times-amendments would have to be made to the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act 1981. I reiterate at this point that the intention of this Bill is to remove the anomaly inherent in the present 'disadvantaged persons' definition by providing a sliding scale of voluntary contributions through a levy on gross income.

The scheme would work in this way: The present cost of insuring a family with a private health insurance fund is $572 per annum, on which a tax deduction of 32 cents in the dollar applies. I recognise the fact that private health insurance companies are at present engaged in the game of increasing those costs but for the sake of simplicity I will have to stick to the ones operating at present. Thus, at the moment, actual family rates for health insurance amount to $389 per annum. The single rate of insurance is presently $286 per annum, less the 32 cents in the dollar tax concession, producing an actual cost of $194 per annum.

I say at this point that the introduction of tax deductibility for health insurance fund contributions is long overdue and something for which the present Government is to be congratulated. The present disadvantaged cut-off points are $96 a week for a single person-that is, approximately $5,000 a year-and $160 a week for a married couple, with an additional $20 a week allowed for each child. The relevant annual figure for a married couple with no children is therefore $8,320 a year. An additional $1,040 a year is allowed for each child.

Under the system we are recommending-that is, that a levy of six cents in the dollar be charged for family insurance-a married couple with no children would begin paying this levy at the present Government cut-off point for disadvantaged persons; that is, at $8,320. At this rate of six cents in the dollar, a couple with no children would have to earn $14,803 a year gross before they were contributing the now basic rate of $389. At this point, no further levy would be charged. Similar figures for a married couple with one child would be: Start of levy, $9,340; and the end of the sliding scale, $15,823. For a married couple with two children the starting point is $10,400 and the cut-off point $16,883. I think the rate for families on lower incomes is significantly different from the one which now applies.

Single people would pay a levy of 3c per dollar operating from $5,000 to a cut-off point of $11,403. For single parent families, similar rates of levy to those operating for married couples would apply; that is, a sole parent with one child would pay the same rate as a married couple with no children while a sole parent with two or more children would pay the same rate as that applying to a married couple in the same situation. In other words, instead of there being the absolute cut-off rate between disadvantaged and non-disadvantaged persons as now applies under the Act thus causing extraordinary hardship to hundreds of thousands of Australians, a sliding scale of contributions would apply. No health insurance costs would be incurred for married couples between $8,320 and $10,400, depending on the number of children and no health insurance costs would be incurred for single people or sole parents earning between $5,000 and $10,400, again depending on the number of children involved.

As far as the mechanics of operation are concerned, I would envisage that, since this Bill is not intended to operate before 1 July 1982, after that date individuals or families who wish to avail themselves of the scheme would do so by filling out a form available from the offices of the Commissioner of Taxation. In addition, a simple change to the taxation form to provide a section in which indication can be given of the health insurance scheme used by the individual concerned would then allow the Treasurer to deduct the required amount of payment due from those opting to pay for their health care cover through the income levy. Payment by the Government to doctors directly or to private health insurance companies for those individuals opting for the levy system would operate in the same way as applies at present to disadvantaged persons and pensioners. We feel that this scheme reduces the burden which is placed on people marginally above the level of income which at present is regarded as making them disadvantaged, without in any way grossly overburdening government revenue. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Messner) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Macklin) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Customs Act 1901.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before Senator Macklin rises to move that the Bill be read a second time I remind the Senate that this is the honourable senator's maiden speech in this place. I would ask that the same courtesies be extended to him as are extended to all honourable senators when making their first speech in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

First, Mr President, may I add my congratulations to those of other senators on your election to the position of President of this chamber. Secondly, I would like to make it known that I accept fully the responsibility given to me by the electors of Queensland to represent them in this the States' House of the Commonwealth.

The amendment which I am proposing in the Customs Amendment Bill (No. 2), if carried, will ensure that this Parliament has the opportunity to protect natural areas of outstanding scientific, conservation and recreational value from destruction by sand mining. It does not seek to prohibit all sand mining. Indeed, this Parliament will, with this amendment, be able actively to encourage the export of minerals extracted from sand from those areas which are of economic value only. There are large deposits of mineral sands in Australia which are not located in environmentally sensitive areas such as Moreton and Fraser Islands.

In addition, this amendment will give this Parliament the opportunity to prohibit the export of such minerals when they are likely to be used by nations hostile to Australia, particularly those nations which may wish to seek to use them for military purposes. For example, in the 11 months ended May 1981 we exported to the Soviet Union 5,018 tonnes of rutile valued at $1,671,000. In the free world at least over 90 per cent of rutile is used for the production of paint pigment. However, in the Soviet Union the rutile usage is mainly for missile production.

It has been necessary to bring this Bill before the Senate at this time because the Queensland Government, in not accepting its responsibilities in the areas of conservation and defence, has proceeded with granting sand mining leases for areas of Moreton Island. To point out that Moreton Island is a prime example of a remaining unspoiled coastal area on the doorstep of Australia's third major city is not to take an anti-mining stand. It is merely to state a fact. The Minister responsible for the granting of export licences has not, to date, indicated his intentions to prohibit the export of minerals to be mined from Moreton Island. It is encouraging that the Government senators, in recognising the importance of preventing the sand mining of this island, have elected to bring the second reading of this amendment Bill before the Senate today. I look forward to their further support when they vote for this Bill at the appropriate time.

Moreton Island is of major scientific importance not only environmentally but also archaeologically and biologically. The environmental and aesthetic values of Moreton Island are equal to those of Fraser Island. The particulars regarding the lakes, swamps, vegetation and geography of those sand islands do not require reiteration. This parliament knows of their value. However, Moreton Island has particular importance which is worth mentioning. It is a natural area of outstanding recreational value and a most important scientific and conservation area with considerable landscape value which would warrant consideration in a world heritage list. Of the large sand islands in that region Moreton Island is the least disturbed by man's activities. It is unique in that it is the last major sand island in close proximity to Queensland's capital which could still be regarded as a natural wilderness area. I believe on that basis alone Moreton Island should be preserved intact. Mining 6 per cent of Moreton Island will not leave many of its unique and varied attractions intact. The big and small sandhills, nearly all of Ocean Beach, the rolling heathlands surrounding Blue Lagoon, the west coast and the spectacular high dunes north of Mount Tempest will all be degraded. Thousands of years of Aboriginal history will be gone forever. The best mining technology can not restore such features.

I am not the only one who believes this. One of the heartening aspects of the Moreton Island conservation campaign has been the tremendous public response it has had, particularly in Brisbane. The Institute of Applied Social Research at Griffith University conducted a public opinion poll which showed that 68.1 per cent of the population within the Moreton region were not in favour of sand mining of Moreton Island. It is the opinion of anthropologists in the University of Queensland that this island offers the last remaining site within which the life patterns of the aboriginal inhabitants of Moreton can be pieced together. At least 30 distinguished Australians have attested to this. In an open letter to the Australian people they said:

We consider Moreton Island to be an invaluable resource for flora and fauna conservation, social values including recreation, archaeological and scientific values. Moreton Island is an invaluable natural resource for Queensland and the world. It should be kept for all generations to appreciate. All of Moreton Island should be conserved and managed as a national park.

It has been stated that the minerals to be mined from Moreton Island are of such value to Australia that we must forgo the conservation of Moreton Island to reap their benefits. This is simply not true. The sand mining industry is a capital intensive one with a high degree of foreign ownership and with a majority of its products being exported. At the most only 200 jobs will be created and many of these will be filled by existing employees of the companies involved. It has been estimated that the total revenue to the State Government from royalties, payroll tax and lease rentals would be a mere $4m. Furthermore, a major market for these exports will be the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the rutile will be used in the aircraft and space industries of that country including those for military use. None of the three minerals to be mined from Moreton Island will have a significant impact on the total mined throughout Australia. Rutile, even after excluding existing environmentally protected areas, will only be 4.25 per cent of Australia's total production and both zircon and ilmenite will be less than 2 per cent of Australia's production.

Recent oversupply of world markets has resulted in the cutting back of production for the mineral sands industries of Australia. In the light of this do we need to mine Moreton Island for the benefit of the USSR and to the detriment of Australia's environment? Irrespective of what has been said elsewhere, sand mining is incompatible with conserving Moreton Island and it would endanger its ecological integrity and destroy the natural recreational values that presently attract so many people to that island. Restoration of vegetation cover in mined areas of Moreton Island would require the use of fertilisers. Some native plants are sensitive to phosphate fertilisers and their application may prevent the re-establishment of some types of native plant communities. Should mining proceed on Moreton Island it and the associated infrastructure would jeopardise Moreton Island's status as part of the National Estate.

It is my belief that Moreton Island is an impor- tant part of Australia's natural heritage and for this and the many other reasons that could be stated it should be kept in perpetuity for the people of Queensland and Australia. I believe this Parliament should, as a matter of continuing public debate, bring up from time to time in the consideration of such leases the ongoing debate between conservation and development within this country. I believe it is a debate worthy of this chamber. It is a debate in which we must all take part. I look forward to the support of honourable senators and I commend this Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Messner) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Haines) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Banking Act 1959.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to ensure, firstly, that regulations are made under the principal Act for the control of increases in interest rates; secondly, that those regulations grant relief from increases in interest rates to families borrowing funds for the purchase of their first home; and thirdly, that Parliament has control of increases in interest rates of more than 0.5 per cent.

Mr President, as you are no doubt aware, one of the traditional dreams of Australians is to own their own home. Indeed, Australia has one of the highest rates of home ownership in the world. It hardly needs stating, therefore, that rises in interest rates generally, and home loan interest rates in particular, have a devastating effect on individuals and families either already in possession of a mortgage or planning on applying for a loan to buy or build a house.

Constantly increasing interest rates have a staggering effect on these people. They make future budgetary planning almost impossible and I remind honourable senators that, unlike governments, householders in Australia are not encouraged to run at massive annual deficits. Those most affected, of course, are the poor, although middle income earners are also hard hit. Newly married couples have no chance of planning for the future under a system of constantly rising interest rates. They are forced out of the home market and into the rental or welfare housing market. Statistics on the value of total home loans show that there has been no real increase in these loans since the 1976-77 financial year, despite the fact that there has been a very real need for more loans. If the present Government's blinkered attitude to interest rate increases continues, I predict that these young couples and any family they can afford to have will be forced into the tent owning market. I say this advisedly and not frivolously.

When home loan interest rates rise, rentals inevitably follow either because the landlord has a mortgage as well or because he senses a high demand in a dwindling supply situation. A growing number of individuals and families can afford neither a home loan nor high weekly rental. In South Australia, a recent study by the South Australian Housing Trust reveals that between July 1980 and June 1981, the average rental price of houses rose from $56 per week to $65 per week, while those for flats and units rose from $38 to $44 per week. As South Australian house prices are generally lower than those in the eastern States, I imagine that the situation is even worse in Victoria, New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory. That there is a limited supply of rental accommodation and that what there is is outside the price range of those people who are finding it impossible to qualify for or keep up repayments on mortgages, is reflected in the ever increasing demand for housing trust or housing commission homes. Australia wide, there has been a record number of applications for the provision of welfare housing in the last 12 months. In South Australia, the jump has been of the order of 12 per cent in 1980-81, and this follows an increase of 9 per cent in 1979-80.

After last night's Budget it is clear that we can expect this trend to continue. The fact that Federal Government funding to the States for housing has dropped from $280m in 1978-79 to $108m in 1981-82 will serve only to exacerbate the problem. Public rental stocks are already at a record low. The wait for home loans is increasing and the cost of even an average home mortage repayment is prohibitive. The pressure of demand on welfare housing is rising dramatically. I repeat my prediction that if this trend continues, and it appears inevitable that it will, we will be faced with a generation of tent dwellers-a fact which will probably prompt the Government only to increase sales tax on tents! An even more troubling result of the fact that families are finding it difficult if not impossible to afford a roof over their heads, is the domino effect this has, not only on the building industry but also on other sections of business and commerce. Families will be forced to cut back expenditure on other items in order to meet repayments on existing mortgages or in order to afford to rent a roof. The first restraints will be applied to appliances, white goods, and cars. As a final resort, purchases of clothing and then food will be hit. After last night's budgetary announcements it appears that all that most people will be able to afford is to drive to their local bottle shop!

This Bill intends to stop the rot that is eating into the way of life of the majority of ordinary Australians by providing some relief for them of the excessive burden of interest rates facing them at present. It will do this in two main ways. Firstly, it provides for regulations to be made under section 50 of the Banking Act so that a five-year moratorium occurs on interest rate increases for individuals or families taking out a first house loan. Under this system, these people would know that for the first five years of their loan, their interest rate will not increase and, further, that any increase in the rate of interest required to bring the rate of interest to prevailing market levels will be made in stages over the second five years of the loan. This will shift the major burden of repayments from the low income earning years to a period in the lives of most people when they are better able to afford them.

Secondly, it is apparent to many people that the sooner interest rate variations become a matter for the Parliament to decide before the event instead of acquiescing after it, the better. To that end, this Bill provides that the Treasurer shall not grant permission for an increase of more than one half of one per cent per six months in interest rate -unless a statement setting out particulars has been laid before each House of the Parliament and each House of the Parliament has by resolution declared that the Treasurer may grant the required permission. There are those who would say that these days Parliament is merely a rubber stamp of the Executive, and that may well be so. On the other hand, if interest rates have to be approved by Parliament as a whole, then the general public will at least have some opportunity to lobby their local members-a not inconsiderable improvement on the present situation.

I cannot emphasise too strongly that ever-increasing interest rates hit at the very heart of family life in this country. They will not go down by the Government expressing pious hopes that they will. Something has to be done to ease the burden on ordinary Australians and this Bill is one way of doing that. I would hasten to add, however, that the day the Government has the compassion to introduce tax concessions for home loan interest rates with a fair and just means test applying, I will support it wholeheartedly. It is beyond the competence of any senator, however, to introduce such a Bill and this one is the next best thing.

Before the banking industry starts beating its collective breast, I would like to refer at this point to another Bill in my name which seeks to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. The purpose of this second Bill is to encourage savings in finance organisations which lend money for housing, by granting exemption from income tax for the first $1,000 of income from interest paid on savings accounts bearing interest at a rate of 10 per cent or less per annum. The result of this would be to provide a pool of money in relatively low interest bearing accounts in banks and building societies for those organisations to lend out at the low or pegged rates of interest for home loans I mentioned earlier. The result for the investor is simple. If he or she invests, say, $10,000 in an account paying 10 per cent per annum and does not have to pay tax on that, the money has been invested effectively at 14.7 per cent, a rate reasonably compatible with prevailing rates. I hasten to point out that, where an individual earns more than $1,000 interest in such accounts, only the first $1,000 would be exempt from taxation, and where the interest derives from investments in accounts paying more than 10 per cent, no exemption would apply.

It is my belief that, despite their bleatings to the contrary, banking institutions in Australia are not about to go to the wall and must be encouraged to face their responsibilities to Australians other than major investors. I cannot implore the present Government strongly enough to stop playing academic fiscal exercises with the lives and hopes of millions of Australians and, please, to show some real compassion for the ordinary man in the street and the women and children who will soon be sharing that street, quite literally, with him. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Macklin) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act relating to repatriation pensions for pulmonary tuberculosis.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The object of this Bill is a simple one; it is to restore the 100 per cent disability pension to all ex-servicemen and women suffering from tuberculosis and who had contracted it prior to 2 November 1978. In the Federal Budget of 1978, the Government took away several longstanding benefits from those many Australian war veterans who already have and will in future suffer from pulmonary tuberculosis. Their dependents were also stripped of benefits. Among the benefits withdrawn by the Government were: Automatic 100 per cent disability pension for life-first granted in 1922; automatic acceptance and pension for those who served in a theatre of war-first granted in 1943; service pension for TB ex-servicemen and women who served their country but did not have overseas service-first granted in 1936; educational benefits for children of TB ex-servicemen; and recognition of the tubercular condition as if it had resulted from an occurrence which took place during the servicemen's war service.

As people in this Senate chamber will no doubt remember, when our servicemen and women returned in 1945 they were welcomed with ticker-tape, adulation and thanks on the part of the people of this country. In fact, we are able to debate matters today because of the actions of servicemen. Unfortunately we seem to have now forgotten the things done in 1945, and to thank our ex-servicemen and women. That debt remains whether it be 30 years ago or not.

There is no doubt that the Government's action in cutting those benefits in 1978 was a very misguided one. I quote the rationale provided by the then Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Honourable Evan Adermann:

'. . The Government (has) decided that the special provisions which related to pulmonary tuberculosis were no longer appropriate because they were introduced when T.B. was a serious health problem with limited prospects of effective control. The introduction of effective treatment methods, based on new drugs, has changed this situation. The Government considered that, as most pensioners have long since ceased to suffer any extensive actual incapacity from TB, they should, in future, be paid on the same basis as veterans who suffer from other incapacities, that is, on the basis of the actual degree of incapacity suffered'.

I remind the Senate that it was not until the early 1970s that the standard of treatment of pulmonary TB was such as to bring about the situation which the Minister indicated was the reason for the Government's action. He and his departmental advisors conveniently forgot all those veteans whose TB had, for periods of up to 40 years, already gravely affected their lifestyles, and those people were at an age where a reduction in their pension was an economic disaster. Indeed, I have met a number of people who were reduced from 100 per cent disability to 5 per cent and who, for the first time since World War II, had to front up at a social security office and apply for the unemployment benefit. Those people were in their sixties. The Government has repeatedly promised-during the past 60 years-that under no circumstances would this particular pension rate be reduced below 100 per cent of the ordinary rate. I quote a letter dated 14 November, 1947, of which I am sure the Minister of Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) would have hundreds:
' . . . In connection with your war pension . . . You are informed that pension will continue subject to further review, but will not under any circumstances-
I repeat 'under any circumstances'-
be reduced below the ordinary total rate, prescribed by the Australian Soldiers' Repatriation Act.

Senator Messner, the present Minister, has stated that although TB veterans received letters containing the above undertaking, it meant only that the rate of 100 per cent applicable at that time would be paid-for example, inflation was not to be taken into account! He compounded this nonsense by announcing that there was no Government commitment to continue the 100 per cent rate to TB ex-servicemen and women. The Fraser Government was the first government to break this solemn promise to veterans in 56 years. According to Senator Messner's argument, there was no 'legal requirement' for every Government from 1922 to 1978 to continue the pension at the 100 per cent rate, but they did so nevertheless.

It is insufficient for the Government to claim that now there is a 'cure' for tuberculosis it can ignore the long term effects of the disease. Major economic, social and lifestyle changes were wrought on tuberculosis veterans prior to the discovery of the 'cure' and these must continue to be taken into account, even in 1981. One unique characteristic of tuberculosis victims is the stigma of the tuberculosis label, which brought may practical and social problems to affected veterans, and had serious consequences for their employment prospects, their social relationships, their chances of securing superannuation, and also of life insurance. Those veterans still alive continue to suffer from those disabilities that they had in 1945-social and economic disabilities that they suffered at the prime of their lives.

Treatment methods for tuberculosis generally after the First World War were crude and prolonged, and these methods continued until the Second World War when the most common method of treatment for pulmonary tuberculosis was pheumothorax, requiring the injection of air into the chest cavity. These injections of air to keep the lung collapsed were carried out on a weekly or fortnightly basis for periods of five years or more. If that is not a reason why this country should not at least respect those veterans, then I do not know what is. In approximately 1947, chest surgery was introduced. This process involved the risk of loss of life, permanent disfiguration and very painful post operative effects. Can we now say: 'Let us forget about the suffering of those pensioners at that time because there is a cure now'? What has a cure now got to do with it?

In the employment area the tuberculosis veterans were particularly disadvantaged, especially where medical examination was a necessary prerequisite. Some fields-for example, the food industry-were closed completely to such veterans. Many promising careers were cut short and the Minister knows this well. Promotion opportunities were missed and jobs lost because medical officers told veterans not to push themselves, to take things easy and take time off. They had those painful surgeries for up to five years or longer at a time when most people were establishing their economic livelihood and their families. Does that not continue to 1981? It is understandable, therefore, that, with their life opportunities greatly reduced, the 100 per cent rate disability pension-designed specifically for those veterans -should continue. How can the Minister for Veterans' Affairs then say what he said in correspondence? He said:

I reiterate the Government's belief that its current policy in respect of these veterans is a generous one, is reasonable and equitable, and places these veterans on the same basis as other veterans who receive a disability pension.
It does nothing of the sort.

In closing, may I draw particular attention to clause 19 of my Bill, which has the effect of ensuring that any increased expenditure by the Commonwealth which results from the amendments in the Bill is not made out of the standing appropriations of the Consolidated Revenue Fund as provided for in the Repatriation Act and in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act and may only be provided out of an appropriation made by the Parliament for the purpose in the future. The inclusion of clause 19 is intended to prevent the Bill from being treated as a proposed law for the appropriation of revenue or moneys. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
