PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 June, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the Crimes (Currency) Bill, the purpose of which is to update, consolidate and revise all existing Australian law, State and Federal, which relates to the counterfeiting of currency, both notes and coin, domestic and foreign and also the counterfeiting of bonds and securities which are issued by the Commonwealth and foreign governments.

SPEECH.PARA: Another object of the Bill is to enable Australia to accede to the International Convention for the Suppression of Counterfeiting Currency, a treaty which was in fact first entered into under the auspices of the League of Nations in Geneva back in April 1929. So it cannot be said that Australia has in any way rushed headlong into this particular legislative exercise. It has taken us some 52 years, in this instance, to get our legislative act together.

The Bill is a legitimate one because it is based on a quite inadequate existing law so far as counterfeiting is concerned. There is a spectacular lack of uniformity-despite the clear constitutional power which has existed in the Commonwealth since the turn of the century to override it-between the Commonwealth and the various States in this regard. The State legislation is variable in its coverage and is scattered through a variety of different Acts; for example, the New South Wales Crimes Act 1900, Part V; the Victorian Crimes Act 1958, Division 4; and the South Australian Criminal Law Consolidation Act 1935, Part VI, all of which deal with forgery. The State legislation in question does not uniformly protect foreign currency and in some cases provides quite different penalties for offences in respect of domestic currency on the one hand and foreign currency on the other.

Then we have a package of Commonwealth legislation which again wobbles about as between a variety of Acts-the Reserve Bank Act 1959, sections 46 to 55; the Crimes Act 1914, Part IV of which deals with coinage and Part V with forgery; the Treasury Bills Act 1914, sections 13 and 13A; the Commonwealth Inscribed Stock Act 1911, sections 48 to 51; and the Currency Act 1965, section 22.

The mere recitation of that diversity of legislative bases for the present law makes clear the necessity for some rationalising piece of legislation such as this. The existing Commonwealth legislation does not protect adequately foreign currency. For example, the Crimes Act relates only to current coin, so described, that is, coins minted in any part of the Queen's Dominions. Similarly, the Reserve Bank Act deals only with paper money offences relating to Australian notes. One may compare this with the obligations which arise under the 1929 Convention, as supplemented in practice by a resolution of the fifth conference of the International Criminal Police Organisation in 1969, which recommended to participating states that provisions in their domestic law with respect to the counterfeiting of currency be supplemented by provisions which dealt with foreign and domestic government bonds and other securities of that kind.

That international law-and in particular the Convention itself-requires that the punishment for, or prevention of, counterfeiting offences apply wherever the offences have been committed on the soil of the nation in question, or the soil of any other country. The convention also requires that each country provide appropriate protection against the counterfeiting of foreign as well as domestic currency in Australia or by Australians. It also provides that there by no differentiation between the scales of punishment in respect of the domestic currency in question on the one hand and foreign currency on the other.

The object of the legislation is to resolve, consolidate and codify the extraordinarily diverse muddle of domestic laws, both Commonwealth and State, which apply in this area and to bring our Australian law to a condition which satisfies international law and enables Australians to accede to the convention in question. Accordingly the reforms that are effected by this Bill are as follows: The legislation now applies to the counterfeiting of Australian and foreign coin, paper money and also government securities and stock of both Australian and foreign countries; it provides for penalties to be the same whether Australian or foreign currency or bonds are involved; it repeals the existing Commonwealth legislation which bears upon this; and it imposes heavy penalties for all classes of offences relating to counterfeiting, which penalties are consistent, by and large, with existing offences and with the seriousness of the offences in question.

The Bill creates a couple of new offences: Clause 18 relates to the possession of disfigured or defaced Australian currency and clause 19 relates to the designing, making, printing and so on of facsimiles of Australian paper money and securities which might be mistaken for the real thing. The Bill also provides for jurisdiction in these matters to be exercised by the relevant State courts.

There are perhaps only three or four specific issues which require explicit mention. One of them perhaps concerns the extra-territorial operation of this Bill. Clause 5 on the face of it is pretty far reaching to the extent that it applies the operation of this legislation rather unusually: Not only does it make provision in relation to people operating within Australia but also it gives the Bill a completely extra-territorial operation; it does not limit it territorially in any way. However, that is qualified by clause 23 which makes it clear that persons are liable to be charged for offences under this legislation only if the offence in question is committed by a person within Australia or on an Australian ship or aircraft, or, if it happens to be committed overseas, if it is committed in relation to Australian money.

Clearly, the object of that is to protect the Australian currency in situations, which are regrettably increasingly applying today, of international risk to a nation's currency. Such is the ease of communication both physically and otherwise these days there is a genuine risk to the Australian economy of Australian currency being forged or counterfeited outside the country and brought within it. This aspect of the law in question enables the reach of Australian jurisdiction to extend to that situation.

The second aspect of the Bill requires some comment. It will indeed be the subject of a Committee stage amendment by the Opposition, which amendment I hope will be supported by a majority of honourable senators in this place. In this particular respect it will perhaps be an interesting test of good faith. The second matter I draw attention to is one of some concern. It relates to the power to seize forfeited articles under this legislation. At the moment the way the Bill is drawn the power to seize is conferred absolutely and it is not required that the constable or Customs officers in question have a warrant in order to accomplish the seizure of the forfeited article in question.

The relevant clause is clause 29. Perhaps we will refer again to this clause in a little more detail in the Committee stage of the debate. The relevant articles include not only those in the form of counterfeit money itself but also materials which may be used in the production of counterfeit money. The clause simply provides that any article which is forfeited by virtue of being an article of this type or being reasonably believed to be an article of this type can simply be seized without warrant. In fact, this means that if an officer happens to believe that a printing press may have been employed for suspect purposes in this respect that printing press, however valuable it might be, can in fact simply be seized without warrant.

The Opposition regards it as obvious that seizure without warrant of counterfeit currency in particular and other moveable articles that might be involved in the production of it might in circumstances of urgency need to be accomplished without warrant. On the other hand, we take the view that it is most unfortunate for legislation like this, or indeed Commonwealth legislation generally, to be scattered with these sorts of provisions which make no allowance for requirement of a warrant in circumstances where there is no urgency involved because of any concern about the loss or destruction of the article in question.

In the Committee stage we will in fact be moving an amendment to delete the requirement that all such seizures can in fact be accomplished without warrant. We will substitute a provision stating that normally a warrant should be required except in circumstances of urgency where the article might reasonably be regarded as likely to be lost or destroyed if a warrant is sought before the seizure takes place. Certainly that is consistent with the kind of attitude that the Labor Party can be expected to take consistently in this chamber, as indeed it has taken in the past. That is, while supporting the general thrust of legislation we will be very alert to particular clauses within a Bill which we might otherwise support and which in fact can be regarded as overbroad or infringing legitimate claims of civil liberty. We will move that amendment. I think that will constitute an interesting test case of the good faith of this chamber in that respect.

A couple of other matters perhaps need brief mention. The main offences provided for in the Bill in clauses 6 to 13 carry, for the most part, custodial penalties only with no alternative provision for a fine being made. There seems to be no particularly clear or obvious reason why the alternative of a financial penalty should not have been specifically made available to the court in respect of these offences in appropriate cases. One might have thought that on the scale of parallel penalties adopted elsewhere in this Bill-for example, in the new uniform national companies Act-the alternative to 10 years imprisonment should be a fine of around $20,000, the alternative to 12 years imprisonment a fine of $24,000 and the alternative to 14 years, another penalty which recurs in this Bill, a fine of $28,000. I will be interested to hear from the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in his reply why this pattern of alternatives has not been applied systematically throughout this Bill.

There is a point I think worth making-we will not push it to the stage of division in the Committee stage-but again the Opposition would be interested to hear from the Attorney why the language of the Bill is as it is. Clause 19 makes it an offence to design, make, print or distribute certain materials. The test set out in that clause is that the offending material 'so resembles current paper money . . . as to be capable of misleading a person into believing that it is that current paper money'. That is a rather broad test. The language is very broad and seems to be broader than the test of 'likely to mislead or deceive' which appears, for example, in section 52 of the Trade Practices Act.

It seems that under this legislation all that has to be shown is that the material be capable of misleading a single person in the community, however gullible that person might be. Again, I think there is something to be said for the Attorney taking note of this point and indicating whether he is in fact satisfied that the expression 'capable of misleading a person' is in fact a satisfactorily narrow and precise definition of what is required if this section is not to have overbroad, overkill kind of operation.

They are the matters that the Opposition desires to raise with respect to this Bill. As I said, it is a somewhat overdue legislative initiative since it has taken something like 52 years to reach the statute book since the Convention was first opened for signature in Geneva back in 1929. The Opposition makes the point in these circumstances, as indeed we tolerantly do in many others, that it is better late than never.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Crimes (Currency) Bill 1981. We will be supporting the second reading of the Bill, as I presume the Australian Labor Party will do. The Bill covers the counterfeiting of currency, both domestic and foreign. This Bill is reciprocal legislation which enables Australia to join the United Nations International Convention for the Suppression of Counterfeiting Currency. As Senator Evans indicated, the reason we have not been able to join the Convention in the past is that we have not had the domestic legislation to enable us to do so. This Bill provides that domestic legislation which will allow us to join the Convention.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two matters in the Bill that are not required by the Convention but which, notwithstanding, are included in this legislation. The Australian Democrats concur with both of those matters. The first matter relates to the counterfeiting of both foreign and domestic government bonds and securities and the second relates to the reproduction of coins of numismatic interest. I wonder why we use the word 'numismatic' when 'of interest to coin collectors' would be much simpler and would convey the point more accurately and more clearly.

I have heard the amendments which are proposed. Senator Evans was courteous enough to give us good notice of the suggested amendments which he proposes to move on behalf of the Australian Labor Party. They are amendments with which the Australian Democrats concur. We believe the amendments cover the case where immediate action is 'necessary'. We further note that they are in line with the Australian Law Reform Commission's recommendations. We are pleased to support the Bill. We commend the Government for bringing it in. At the Committe stage of the Bill we will be supporting the Labor Party's amendments. We would commend that the Government give due consideration to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the other Opposition speakers in welcoming this legislation. Initially one might express some surprise that no Government members have risen along with those on this side of the chamber to welcome this legislation. This type of legislation has a very long lineage. Authorities in societies from many thousands of years B.C. have been concerned to prevent the counterfeiting of coins and currency.
—That was Senator Puplick.

—I am trying to put into perspective the honourable senator's concern. The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) is perhaps 50 years further on than the International Convention for the Suppression of Counterfeiting Currency to which Australia is now acceding. What I am saying here is that in the overall international historical perspective, Senator Durack has really acted most expeditiously. Coins came into existence many thousands of years B.C. They were usually stamped in the shape of animals and therefore, doubled as decoration and so on. In times closer to our great turning point from B.C. they were actually made into wedge shapes which gave us the Latin word for coin. It has always been a concern of those in political authority to ensure that the coins and currencies of the realms not be counterfeited or forged.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans expressed some concern that the offences provided for under this legislation in respect of natural persons permitted penalties to be imposed only in the nature of imprisonment, for up to 12 years in some cases or a maximum of 14 years in others. The history of laws dealing with counterfeiting show that these are very mild penalties indeed. In common law and in the legislation of the United Kingdom, counterfeiting was always regarded as high treason. In the very early statute of treason of 1352, when the King was required to state under pressure from the Commons those seven cases which would be high treason-because lands in that case were forfeited to him rather than the immediate lord of the person concerned-two of those seven heads of treason were to do with counterfeiting. The penalties in that case were extreme and severe. As Senator Evans would be pleased to know, this legislation is well in accord with, and indeed milder than, that which has been a part of our history.

TALK.START.PARA: —Were any of the First Fleet counterfeiters?

—It is very interesting that Senator Mulvihill should raise that question because I think I know the answer. Whilst some of the convicts brought out to Australia may well have been guilty of such a crime, the fact is that the First Fleet arrived here with no money. At the time of King George III, I think, England was in such a state of political and economic turmoil that there was hardly enough coin for the realm within the shores of the United Kingdom, let alone for the newly established convict settlements in the great southern waters. So when the First Fleet arrived in Australia there was a provision of the necessities of life from the commissariat of the colony. There was even no barter or exchange; everything was provided. When the early governors required greater supplies or sums of money they used to send to the Cape for such supplies. Of course, this led to the early circulation of rum as a desirable medium of exchange. This was used and abused by those officers who had access to it and those members of the armed forces who received rum as part of their ration and pay.
—They had no Coke to have with it, though.

—The honourable senator has mentioned the international aspects of this problem. I thank him for his helpful interjections. It is a fact that the Government is presenting this legislation to the chamber at this time because of its accession to the international covenant. Senator Mulvihill has mentioned a commodity that is well known internationally which emanated from the United States of America. One recalls that about this time last year-16 August 1980-the Australian Federal Police seized counterfeit United States banknotes in Australia with a value of more than $1m in a raid on a house in Peakhurst. Peakhurst, if not in Senator Mulvihill's area, is certainly well known to him.
—It is in the mother State.

—Yes. That was the largest seizure of counterfeiting material in Australia for some years. Under this legislation Australia does accept responsibility for not only preventing the counterfeiting of its own money within Australia but also the counterfeiting of the money or coin of those other nations which accede to the covenant. In that respect this legislation does fulfil our international obligations under the Convention for the Suppression of Counterfeiting Currency. It is interesting to note that that too is totally in harmony with the traditions of our common law and legislative heritage from the United Kingdom. In the first year of Mary's reign in 1553 an Act was passed concerning the counterfeiting of strange coins being current within the realm. The preamble may be of interest to the honourable senator. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Forasmuch as by the laws of this realm small and no due and condign punishment is at this present time provided for such evil disposed persons as shall counterfeit or forge such kind of gold or silver of other realms, as is not the proper coin of this realm, and yet permitted and suffered by the Queen our sovereign lady's consent, and heretofore hath been permitted and suffered by the consent of her most noble progenitors, to be currant in payment within this her realm, nor for such persons as shall counterfeit the Queen's highness sign manual, or privy signet or privy seal; by reason whereof divers evil disposed persons are encouraged and boldned daily to perpetrate and commit the said several offences . . .
an offence is created of circulating that foreign counterfeit coin within the realm of England.

TALK.START.PARA: —But those who were republicans would not be impressed, would they?

—Mr President, I am directing my remarks to the chamber through you. I would not wish to engage in a continuous dialogue with Senator Mulvihill. I believe I have made the point that whilst we are acting in accordance with the traditions proper to a parliament which looks to Westminster as one of its progenitors, nevertheless in this legislation we are accepting an international obligation which is entirely contemporary and it is entirely proper that Australia undertake it. In that respect the Opposition entirely supports the Crimes (Currency) Bill. We do have a misgiving which has been well expressed by Senator Evans insofar as a police constable can seize, without warrant, counterfeit currency, coins or, more particularly, machinery which he reasonably suspects to have been involved in the production of such counterfeit currency or coins. We simply say that unless there is a case of urgency a warrant ought to be argued for before a judge or magistrate before the seizure of such property takes place. In that minor but important respect I support the amendment which will be moved by Senator Evans. On the whole, as I have said, I join in welcoming this legislation and commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its support of this measure. It is an important one because it achieves a codification for Australia as a whole of crimes relating to the currency, which is very vital to our economic life. It is surprising that we have not previously had a measure of this kind. I must apologise to the Senate that the opportunity did not present itself 50 years ago, and that I was not in a position to do something about it at the time. Forgive me, but I have done the best I can in doing something about it within the opportunities that have been presented to me. Certainly, acceding to the international convention on this subject is another advantage we will achieve by the passage of this measure. I think the Senate will be making a major contribution to the enforcement of our currency laws by giving this Bill a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had notice of the amendment that will be moved by Senator Evans to a clause of the Bill. I also note that Senator Chipp has already informed the Senate that he proposes to support the measure, which surprises me somewhat. I thought that the policy of the Australian Democrats was to wait to hear the arguments in this chamber before they made decisions on matters. As yet, we have not had any debate on the subject, and I would like to hear some debate on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are going to issue their own currency.

—That really does not affect the major provisions of the legislation, but it is an important matter. I think Senator Evans's amendment may have ignored some important principles on this subject that have been established in the common law, but I have an open mind, as I always do on law reform matters, and I propose to listen to Senator Evans on the subject. I had hoped that the Australian Democrats would also listen to him, and listen to what I may say about it as well.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not a matter of great urgency and I think we ought to give it full attention. I will propose, when we go into the Committee stages, that we adjourn the debate to another occasion so that that I can give the argument the fullest attention before I commit the Government to it. However, that is a peripheral matter. I am pleased that the Senate will support this measure and hope that the Bill will have a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As mentioned by Senator Evans in his second reading speech, the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Bill is based on the recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission. Indeed, the Commission's report No. 16, tabled in Parliament on 16 September 1980, contained draft legislation which is almost identical with the provisions in the private member's Bill before the Senate. The Government has completed a careful examination of the recommendations put forward by the Commission. On 10 June 1981 the Treasurer (Mr Howard) outlined the reasons why the Government had decided not to introduce legislation to regulate the activities of insurance brokers. The private member's Bill does not introduce any new approaches to the issues surrounding the question of broker regulation beyond those cavassed by the Law Reform Commission. Accordingly, the Government is not in favour of this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: In the first place, the Government's general view on intervention in commercial relationships is that a clear need must be demonstrated before Commonwealth regulatory legislation is considered. The Government's view in this case is that such a need has not been established. It is also recognised that the States traditionally are the regulators of intermediaries such as solicitors and estate agents, and in areas of general consumer protection. Those on other side of the Senate may wish to centralise all power at the Federal level, but that is not the objective of this Government. We are fortified in our approach to this matter by the fact that the vast majority of broker transactions have been conducted in a satisfactory manner. The figures of losses from broker insolvencies played upon by Senator Evans ought to be seen in a proper context. The fact is that losses from broker insolvencies as cited by the Law Reform Commission, that is, known insolvencies, in the 10 years preceding the Commission's report, represent less than 0.1 per cent of premiums handled by brokers.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very small amount.

— It is a small amount. Furthermore, based on the Law Reform Commission's analysis, 92 per cent of the known losses arising from broker insolvencies represented amounts due to insurers. In addition, businesses, which could properly be expected to look after their own commercial interests, make up the largest proportion of brokers' clientele. All this suggests that only a very small proportion of the losses would have fallen on the individual consumer. Accordingly, the Government's view remains that the most effective approach to the basic issues relating to insurance brokers is the development of sound self-regulatory practices. With self-regulation, consumers are given the freedom to choose to deal with intermediaries subject to such arrangements or, if they prefer, to seek services elsewhere in the market. There is no shortage of readily identifiable insurance brokers subject to self-regulatory arrangements at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the Government has taken note of the traditional practice in the general insurance industry whereby brokers in effect obtain extended credit, which in turn enables them either to extend credit to clients or to hold premium moneys for periods exceeding normal business practice before the moneys are transmitted to insurers. While it is evident that the great majority of brokers handle these moneys in a responsible manner, some circumscribing of dependence on extended credit may be appropriate. The Treasurer has said in regard to this particular aspect that consideration will be given, in consultation with the insurance industry, to amending the Insurance Act 1973 to give effect to this objective, provided that it can be done without undue regulation or administrative cost. I am advised that the initial industry reaction to the idea has been positive.
On the question of the commercially interested parties in this matter, I must correct Senator Evans's assertion in his second reading speech, which stated:

. . . there has been a striking unanimity in the calls for compulsory regulation of brokers, for professional indemnity insurance and for implementation of the Law Reform Commission's other recommendations.

In fact, we are advised by the major insurance industry bodies, representing both insurance brokers and underwriters, that they are most concerned about a number of provisions of the kind contained in the Bill, for example, the provisions in clause 11 under which insurance intermediaries would be deemed to be the agents of the insurer and not of the insured, and the provisions in clause 25 which require a broker to give the insured details of the remuneration received by him from the insurer in respect of the insured's contract.

The honourable senator made a number of references to the various processes that have gone on in the past to explore the possibility of regulation in this area. It is true that the Government has looked at this difficult area on more than one occasion and had examined a variety of proposals put forward by the industry prior to the commencement of work in this area by the Law Reform Commission. The various studies undertaken in this area, both prior and subsequent to the Commission's report, have shown that significant costs would be involved in establishing a comprehensive regulatory scheme in this area and that many of the problems involved, including the possibility of broker failure, would remain. It is well recognised that a number of States either have legislated or are foreshadowing legislation in this area. To the extent that the interested parties feel that it is important to achieve consistency between State legislation, I point out that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has informed the States that the Government stands ready to assist in that process.

In conclusion, as the Treasurer has said, the Government is conscious that there will be some in the community who will be disappointed that the Government has not embarked upon the course of full scale regulatory legislation. However, governments have to justify the costs of regulatory intervention by establishing a clear public interest in so intervening. It is often claimed that the only answer to default and dishonesty is to pass more legislation. On the contrary, whilst legislation can go some way towards reducing bad and inefficient practices, no amount of legislation can provide a guarantee against fraud and business failures. At the same time, the attempt to provide such a guarantee in this case would inevitably bring with it an unacceptable level of intervention in the affairs of businesses and individuals. Accordingly, the Government opposes the Bill.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Commonwealth Banking Act have provisions that allow the Commonwealth Bank to terminate a depositor's right to interest if his account has been inactive for seven years, and that after a further ten years allow it to confiscate all the funds in his bank account.
(2) Do any other banks or financial institutions follow similar provisions; if so, which banks and institutions.

(3) Is a depositor warned of these provisions when he opens an account with the Commonwealth Bank, and is the bank obliged to trace and inform the depositor before the provisions of the Act are enforced; if not, will the Treasurer take steps to ensure that in future the Commonwealth Bank informs depositors of these provisions and that it makes a thorough search for a depositor before applying these provisions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Section 53 of the Commonwealth Banks Act, relating to unclaimed deposits with the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, provides that where there has not, for a period of not less than seven years, been any operation on the account by deposit or withdrawal and the pass book has not been presented to the Savings Bank (for example, for crediting of interest), all moneys standing to the credit of the account may be credited to the Depositors' Unclaimed Fund, and shall thereupon cease to bear interest. The Savings Bank, if satisfied that a person is entitled to money which has been credited to the Depositor's Unclaimed Fund, may make payment of the money to him. A list of accounts with balances of $20 or more credited to the Depositors' Unclaimed Fund is required to be published annually in the Australian Government Gazette. The Act provides that all moneys in respect of which a claim is not established within ten years after being credited to the Depositors' Unclaimed Fund cease to be claimable and become the absolute property of the Savings Bank; however the Savings Bank may allow any claim after the expiration of that period if it is satisfied that special reasons exist for the payment of the claim.

For trading banks subject to the Banking Act, including the Commonwealth Trading Bank, the provisions concerning the treatment of unclaimed moneys are set out in section 69 of that Act. In summary, moneys held in an account which has not been operated on for seven years are paid to the Commonwealth Government and held in a Trust Fund. A list of accounts with balances of $20 or more is required to be published annually in the Australian Government Gazette. After six years in the Trust Fund, moneys remaining unclaimed are paid to the Consolidated Revenue Fund. At any time it is possible for a person to provide evidence establishing a claim over the moneys in which case the moneys are refunded through the bank concerned.

(2) The private trading banks are subject to section 69 of the Banking Act (see (1)) in their treatment of unclaimed deposits. There is no corresponding legislative provision covering unclaimed moneys held by the private savings banks.

Section 106 of the Life Insurance Act 1945 governs the treatment of unclaimed moneys held by life insurance companies. Under those provisions life insurance companies are required to pay unclaimed moneys to the Treasurer; however, the provisions allow for subsequent payments to be made from those moneys in satisfaction of valid claims.

The treatment of unclaimed moneys by businesses registered in the Australian Capital Territory (apart from banks, but including such financial institutions as building societies and credit unions) is subject to the Unclaimed Moneys Ordinance 1950. Pursuant to that Ordinance, the details of moneys payable but not claimed within six years are entered into a company register and, in due course, forwarded to the Treasurer. These details are subsequently published in the Gazette and at the elapse of 13 months from Gazettal the moneys are payable by the business to the Commonwealth of Australia. The payments of the moneys to the Commonwealth relieve the business of any further liability relating to the moneys. Any subsequent claim must be settled through the Supreme Court.

Beyond the above arrangements, I understand there would be State legislation governing aspects of the treatment of unclaimed moneys in respect of various financial institutions. The precise arrangements are, of course, matters for the States concerned.

(3) The Managing Director of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation has advised that it is not the practice of the Commonwealth Banks to specially advise customers, on the opening of either trading or savings accounts, of the respective effects of Section 69 of the Banking Act 1959 or Section 53 of the Commonwealth Banks Act 1959 on these accounts. The Commonwealth Banks are not obliged to inform depositors before the provisions of these Acts are enforced. However, the Managing Director advises that the amount of money unclaimed in respect of the Commonwealth Trading Bank is quite small and almost invariably the accounts affected are those of customers for whom correspondence, statements, etc have been returned unclaimed for an extended period. With regard to the Savings Bank, under present procedures the bank writes to all affected depositors with a balance of $1 or more. Where the balance is $20 or more a second advice is sent. For larger balances the bank makes considerable effort to trace account holders before transfer of the relevant balances in terms of the Act.

The Managing Director has added that the Commonwealth Banks will, subject to identification, pay all claims received for balances dealt with in terms of the Acts. In appropriate cases, an ex-gratia payment is made equivalent to Commonwealth Savings Bank deposit interest forgone.
On the basis of the above information it would appear that the efforts made by the banks to trace owners of unclaimed moneys are reasonable and appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 4 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Communications aware that there is concern among ethnic press interests in Australia that community service announcements on ethnic radio are being used as advertising on behalf of ethnic clubs.
(2) Has any action been taken to ensure that genuine community services announcements are carefully distinguished from announcements with an advertising content.
(3) What guidelines apply to the acceptance of community services announcements on 2EA and 3EA.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised by the Special Broadcasting Service, as the authority responsible for ethnic radio stations 2EA and 3EA that its guidelines for broadcasters and co-ordinators, which have been operative for the past two and one half years, are quite specific in relation to both community announcements and commercial messages, namely-

4.1 Radio 2EA/3EA is a station operated by SBS and funded by government. It is precluded from broadcasting commercial messages. All acknowledgements must be approved by station management before going to air.

5.1 Announcements of forthcoming functions to be held by community organisations (non-profit bodies) may be mentioned once only in each program and in no more than three programs. The announcements should be concise giving basic details-for example 'The German Welfare League will be holding a dance at the Parramatta Town Hall on Friday, 25 April. The dance begins at 8 pm and tickets are for sale at the door at $4.50 each.'

In conveying useful information to ethnic communities, the SBS does not wish to place itself in a competitive situation with private enterprise, including the foreign language press, that may draw legitimate sources of advertising revenue from some community organisations operating as trading entities. For example: registered clubs limited by guarantee, movie houses, etc.

However, the SBS believes that ethnic radio language programs should carry all information that is of genuine community interest and which is a service to communities. The SBS considers ethnic radio should reinforce public awareness of all community functions and entertainments of general interest.

The SBS will undertake not to accept for broadcast, announcements about functions, concerts, registered club activities or movie theatre programs if adequate proof is submitted to the SBS by media outlets that announcements on SBS stations are resulting in a regular loss of revenue to the companies concerned. In this respect the onus will be on the publishing organisations concerned to advise the SBS of any changes in their trading arrangements with specific clients that may appear to be taking advantage of free promotion on ethnic radio.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 25 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister for Transport approve of the fact that both Trans-Australia Airlines and Ansett's annual reports were presented almost nine months after the period to which the reports pertained, had expired.

(2) Does the Minister for Transport approve of the very cursory nature of the Ansett report, which makes it impossible for the Parliament to appreciate fully, how Ansett's profits and losses break down into component profits and losses.
(3) Are the reports required from the two major airline instrumentalities required by different pieces of legislation.

(4) Do both the pieces of legislation requiring reports, require those reports to be in such form as the Minister for Transport (with regard to Ansett) or the Treasurer (with regard to TAA) requires, and has the practice grown up, in effect requiring, or at least receiving, a greater degree of accountability from TAA, than from Ansett; if so, in what ways has TAA's accountability been greater.
(5) Is Ansett permitted a lesser degree of accountability, and are Ansett's profits ensured by duopolistic regulation; if so, why.
(6) Will the Minister for Transport use the right given to him in Clause 11(2) of the Airlines Agreement, to approve the form in which a report is made, to ensure greater accountability of Ansett.

(7) Is the Minister for Transport taking any action in order to ensure (a) the fullest disclosure from both airlines; and (b) an equal obligation on both airlines to disclose information to the Parliament; if so, what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There were special circumstances which prevented the annual reports of Trans-Australia Airlines and Ansett being presented earlier to Parliament. In the first place, Parliament rose early in September to prepare for the elections. Secondly, other urgent Government business took precedence over the tabling of these reports in the two-week Parliamentary session in December. As a result, both reports were held over until the Autumn sitting of Parliament.
(2) The financial information presented to Parliament relating to the operation of air services by Ansett Transport Industries Limited complies with Section 11 of the Airlines Agreement Act 1972.
(4) Yes. Section 40 of the Australian National Airlines Act 1945-1973 requires TAA to furnish additional information pertaining to their financial status, other than the normal financial statements.

(5) No. Ansett Airlines, as part of Ansett Transport Industries Limited, operates as a private company and as such, conforms with the requirements of the appropriate companies act. There is no guarantee provided in any Commonwealth legislation ensuring Ansett's profits.

(6) and (7) As indicated in the Minister's second reading speech when presenting the Airlines Agreement Bill 1981 substantially increased reporting obligations have been placed on the airlines by this agreement. Clauses 7, 13 and 23 particularly refer. Annual reports must be made on the use of the consultation arrangements, each airline's trunk route and total airline's financial performance and on the operation of the agreement. These reports will of course be provided to Parliament.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Whitlam Labor Government purchase the Fawnmac group of pharmaceutical manufacturing companies in 1975 for approximately $9,000,000, whereas in 1973 the companies had been bought by Unitas Holdings for only $3,000,000.
(2) Did the tangible or the intangible assets of the Fawnmac companies appreciate significantly between 1973 and 1975; if not, why did the Labor Government pay so much for the companies.

(3) Why did the present Government sell the Fawnmac companies to Sigma Ltd for only $4,850,000 in 1980, despite expert advice that the sale would result in a massive loss of tax-payers' money and that the companies should be retained by the Government and utilised in the public interest.
(4) Will the Minister for Health permit Senator Chipp to peruse all files held by the Government which are relevant to the preceding questions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The terms of purchase of the Fawnmac group of pharmaceutical manufacturing companies were established in July 1974 under an option arrangement negotiated by the Australian Industry Development Corporation. The option to purchase the Fawnmac group was exercised by the Government in July 1975 for an amount of $8,735,595. The purchase price was determined having regard to the earning capacity of the Fawnmac Group rather than on the value of its tangible assets and was influenced by an improvement in profitability of the group during the 1974-75 financial year.

(3) The present Government sold the Fawnmac group of companies as it did not believe it should be in the field of private enterprise. The normal procedures relating to sale of Government assets, calling tenders for the purchase of the Fawnmac group were undertaken in this instance by the Department of Administrative Services. The sale was made to Sigma Ltd which was the highest tendering Australian owned company.

(4) The files referred to by the honourable senator consist primarily of internal working documents which are ordinarily confidential. If, however, the honourable senator can identify the particular matter that is of concern to him I will consider what information can be provided.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Numerical Meteorology Research Centre Advisory Committee

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) As a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, is the Australian Numerical Meteorological Research Centre Advisory Committee to be abolished.
(2) What were the functions of that institution.
(3) Was it performing its functions inadequately in any way and, if so, in what way was it inadequate.
(4) What action is proposed to take over the functions originally performed by the Australian Numerical Meteorological Research Centre Advisory Committee.
(5) As a result of the action, what Government services can be expected to be affected, and in what way will they be affected.

(6) As a result of the action will any information which was available in the past not be available; if so, what is the nature of that information, and in what ways has it proved useful when it was available.

(7) As a result of the Review will any informed advice or co-ordinating capacity which was available in the past not be available; if so, what is the nature of that informed advice or co-ordinating capacity, and in what ways has it proved useful when it was available.
(8) What is the estimated saving in abolishing the Australian Numerical Meteorological Research Centre Advisory Committee.

(9) What is the estimated short and long term cost of not having the services of the Australian Numerical Meteorological Research Centre Advisory Committee available to the Government and the community.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The functions of the Committee over the period 1974-79 are set out in the following extract from the August 1974 Agreement between the Department of Science and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation on the Australian Numerical Meteorology Research Centre (ANMRC)-a facility operated jointly by the Department and CSIRO to carry out studies of the behaviour of the earths atmosphere with emphasis on general circulation, directed towards improvement in the accuracy and timescale of weather forecasting and towards improvement in understanding the distribution and variations in climate on the earth.

'As its name implies, the Committee will have an advisory function reporting to the Secretary, Department of Science, and the Chairman of the Executive, CSIRO, jointly; it will be responsible for the examination of, and advising on, the appropriate division of responsibilities between the Bureau and the Centre which will best lead to a harmonious and successful achievement of the objectives of the Centre; it will keep under review the program of the Centre; make recommendations on the future work of the Centre, and review and report on past programs especially in relation to the extent that approved objectives are being met. The Committee will report at least annually on the program of the Centre. The Committee will also comment on, but not be responsible for, the annual composite budget of the Centre. The Committee will also advise on the development of practices which will promote the integrity and coherence of the Centre and the quality of its work, includng the monitoring, as the occasion demands, of the staffing and promotional procedures associated with the manning of the Centre.'

The ANMRC was last reviewed in 1979-80 and a revised draft agreement between the Department and CSIRO envisaged an additional lower level 'Coordinating Committee' and an expanded ANMRC 'Advisory Committee on Policy and Programs' with the following functions:
(i) to provide advice to the Officer-in-Charge on the operation of the Centre and its research programs;
(ii) to report annually (or at more frequent intervals when appropriate) and make recommendations to the Chairman of CSIRO and the Secretary of the Department of Science and Technology on:
the research programs of the Centre (on-going and prospective);
the appropriate research responsibilities for the Centre, bearing in mind the research interests of the Bureau, relevant Divisions of the CSIRO and Australian universities;
the extent to which its research results are being implemented operationally by the Bureau;
the effectiveness of the interface between the Centre and the Bureau and collaboration with other meteorological research groups;
(iii) to comment on, but not to be responsible for, the annual composite budget of the Centre;
(iv) to encourage joint programs between the Centre and other agencies and individuals.
The new agreement embodying the above changes had not been finalised at the time of announcement of the Government's decision to abolish the Committee.
(3) The Advisory Committee established under the 1974 agreement had performed its functions adequately.

(4) As I place a high priority on finalising the rationalisation of CSIRO atmospheric research programs with those of the Bureau of Meteorology, a study is being undertaken to consider, inter alia, options for performance of the functions originally performed by the Advisory Committee.
(5) It is unlikely that any Government services will be significantly affected.
(6) The Advisory Committee facilitated the Centre's access to information from outside bodies. It is unlikely that any important information that was previously available will now become unavailable.

(8) The estimated costs (excluding Secretariat and Members' time and salaries) of the operation of the Advisory Committee under the 1974 agreement was approximately $1800 p.a. With the proposed expansion of the Committee from 4 to 6 members (including at least one external academic) the future costs would have been expected to be slightly greater.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 26 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What did the General Manager of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, Sir Talbot Duckmanton, tell a deputation of Australian Journalists' Association members who waited on him to complain about the Nationwide programme's political coverage in the last week of the 1980 federal election campaign (See answer to Question No. 425, Senate Hansard, page No. 1954, dated 13 May 1981).
(2) Did the deputation express concern over the fact that the Treasurer, Mr Howard, was the last political figure interviewed on the programme before the electronic media blackout on 15 October.
(3) Did the deputation express concern at the imbalance between the time given on the programme to the Liberal and National Country parties, and the ALP.
(4) Was their concern borne out by the fact that during the election campaign Nationwide devoted almost a full hour more to the Liberal and National Country parties than to the ALP.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The main points made to the deputation by the general Manager of the Australian Broadcasting Commission were that: (a) he had not spoken to Mr David Barnett at any time during the election campaign; (b) the Commission did not consider that confirmation of the presentation of a balance of views during an election campaign was solely dependent upon a mathematical calculation of time, or on the number of lines of copy in News bulletins. Such a calculation was a useful guide, but no more than that; (c) it was not the Commission's policy to expect complete balance in the amount of time on air given to the Government and the Opposition in any one program series: all programs or News bulletins had to be considered. As an example of the problems created by regarding time on air in any one program series, as the only measurement of balance, it was mentioned that although the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition had each been offered 80 minutes of time on a special phone-in program, the Prime Minister has chosen to take his full 80 minutes while the Leader of the Opposition has used only 53 minutes, although 80 minutes was also available to him; (d) Mr Howard's appearance on Nationwide, on 15 October, had been discusssed by the General Manager with the Chairman and only other Commissioner available and it was considered that the last program of Nationwide, before the election black-out, should include an interview with a representative of the Government as well as the Opposition, in other States New South Wales, and Australian Capital Territory and Western Australia-where the previous night's Nationwide had carried an interview with Mr Hawke following the interview with the Prime Minister.
(3) Concern was expressed at the fact that on Nationwide more time was given to the Government representative than to the Opposition.

(4) As explained in (1), the Commission considered that an assessment of balance in its presentation of political matter during an election period-or at any other time should be made, having regard to the ABC's total program output.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: How are members of religious orders to be regarded in relation to their eligibility for 'disadvantaged' status in the new health care arrangements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: In order to benefit from the disadvantaged persons provisions of the revised health insurance arrangements to come into effect on 1 September 1981, a person must be accepted as a disadvantaged person in his or her own right, or be a dependent of a disadvantaged person. As members of religious orders would not ordinarily meet the definition of dependant in the Health Insurance Act they need to qualify as individuals. Acceptance as a disadvantaged person is dependent on a person passing an income test. It is my understanding that members of religious orders do not usually have significant personal incomes; in fact, they commonly take a vow of poverty. therefore they will normally qualify as disadvantaged persons, provided they are Australian residents.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Government review restrictions placed on women entering specialised operational units of the defence forces in Australia, particularly considering the success experienced by those countries who permit women to join optional units requiring highly trained personnel.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)The Government supports the employment of women in the Defence force subject to the proviso that they should not be involved in combat. This restriction is considered to be a fair reflection of prevailing community attitudes and is the practice in other Western societies.
This policy allows women to be employed on active service within Australia and overseas. But it means that they cannot join operational units which have been established principally as combat units.

Service employments are subject to continuing review. This includes the review of any restrictions placed on particular employments. Such restrictions are removed when they are no longer appropriate to the function of a particular employment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 5 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are certain types of hamsters and gerbils being sold in the Eastern States in the guise of cartoon characters known as 'Wombles' which are a prohibited import?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A joint exercise was conducted recently by officers of the Departments of Health and Business and Consumer Affairs, the Australian Federal Police and Queensland, New South Wales and Victorian State authorities following information that hamsters and gerbils were being offered for sale in a number of locations in Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria. The hamsters were being sold as cartoon characters known as 'Wombles' while the gerbils were being sold as 'Chipmunk Mice'. I understand that the risk of any imported hamsters or gerbils introducing rabies or other diseases would be a major aspect in considering any proposals for importation. No hamsters or gerbils have ever entered this country with the permission of the responsible Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 March 1981 (Hansard, page 781) Senator Young asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, a question without notice relating to production of Nomad aircraft.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

My attention has been drawn to an article entitled 'Nomad Stalled on US Markets' which appeared in the Financial Australian on 8 January 1981, and which would seem to be the reference used by the honourable senator. The article referred to the success of Nomad aircraft sales in the United States of America, and then went on to suggest that Nomad faced production irregularities because of what it called 'Australian government delays in authorising further production'. The article then asserted that the wait for authorisation had 'put a stop to forward ordering of materials and components'.

It is my understanding that the honourable senator's question refers to the period of 18 months (also referred to in the article) between approval for purchase of long lead time materials and components and the authorisation in December last, of production of the latest batch of aircraft to a total of 200.

The period of 18 months has no significance in relation to future production schedules. The current schedule is expected to occupy resources of the Government Aircraft Factories (GAF) until 1984. Concurrently customer demand is being monitored, and the future requirement assessed. If it should appear after consideration of all the factors involved, including the market position, that a further batch of aircraft should be manufactured, I would expect a proposal to be developed by GAF for advance purchase of the necessary long lead time items. The interval between that proposal and consideration of further production would be a matter for judgment based on all the circumstances.
The honourable senator can be assured that the Government will give prompt attention to any proposals put to it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 March 1981, (Hansard, page 782) Senator Lajovic asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Has the Minister noted an item in today's Sydney Morning Herald reporting that a Soviet satellite in orbit over Australia is being blamed for radio interference on radar screens at Sydney airport for the past few weeks? According to the report the signals block out part of the radar screens. Whilst they are not a danger to air traffic movements they are annoying to air traffic controllers who are subjected to intense pressure during peak hours. Will the Minister institute an inquiry into the possible effects of such interference if it becomes intensified and in particular into the fact that the satellite radio system, according to Transport Australia technicians, is being switched off and on, most likely from the ground?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Interference at Sydney Airport radar which was identified as originating from an orbiting satellite was first reported early in June 1980. The interference which was annoying to air traffic operators weakened during the following month and ceased on about 5 July 1980.

Recently, attempts were made by the Department of Transport and the Department of Communications to identify further interference. The interference is not continuous, occurring when a polar orbiting satellite passes over Eastern Australia. The period of one complete earth orbit is about 100 minutes. Interference from the satellite may occur several times during one 24 hour period.

The recent interference may not be from the satellite which caused the interference during June 1980. The frequency band involved 1275 MHz is allocated primarily for radar systems of the type employed at airports. Up until 1 January 1982, the International Radio Regulations of the International Telecommunications Union makes no provision for satellite operations in this band.

A satellite having the same period of rotation as that observed in association with the interference was launched by the USSR on 20 May 1980 as a navigation satellite. The interference is consistent with the characteristics of a telemetry signal that would be expected to be used with a satellite of that type.

From 1 January 1982, the Radio Regulations provide for the operation of a radio navigation satellite in the frequency band immediately below the band in which the interference is being experienced. The service would have to operate on a non-interference basis to radar services.
The interference has not been identified beyond doubt as Russian. If it continues and if it is positively identified, Australia will discuss this with Russia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 31 March 1981 (Hansard, page 885) Senator Mulvihill asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I direct a question to either the Minister representing the Minister for Communications or the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer to the action of the Special Broadcasting Service in consigning Mr Bosi, the Italian co-ordinator, to the sin bin for a week. I wonder whether it would be possible to have the whole of the transcript tabled in the Senate so that we could evaluate this apparent demarcation dispute between co-ordinators and the Australian Journalists' Association.
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Special Broadcasting Service has advised that it terminated Mr Bosi's services on 5 May following a series of long-standing differences with him on policy and operational issues. The sequence of recent events which led to Mr Bosi's suspension and subsequently to his dismissal is, briefly, as follows:
Mr Bosi, in his role as Co-ordinator of the Italian language program, suppressed a news item which had been prominently featured in other news media.

The SBS considered that Mr Bosi's action was a breach of SBS policy and program guidelines and he was suspended after an investigation by a Management Committee of Inquiry which found that there were no grounds for further appeal.
The SBS Board subsequently resolved to censure Mr Bosi but lift the suspension if he provided a written undertaking to comply with SBS policy. Mr Bosi did so.

The SBS considered the matter closed, but Mr Bosi then published letters in Italian language newspapers-Il Globo, La Fiamma, Tutto Press Sport, Settegiorni-making serious and unfounded charges against the SBS Board, management and personnel.
The SBS denied these charges and called upon him in a letter from their solicitors to apologise and retract within seven days.
Mr Bosi did not comply and the SBS agreed to terminate his services, informing him of their decision by letter on 5 May.
Subsequently the SBS, on legal advice, filed a claim for damages in the Supreme Court on 15 May.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1382) Senator Watson asked me a question, without notice, concerning the possible use of the two Royal Australian Air Force VIP B707 aircraft and whether consideration was being given to allowing the international carriers of our near neighbours such as Air Niugini and Air Nauru to service the domestic routes to alleviate the plight of stranded passengers, particularly those in Tasmania, during the flight attendants' dispute.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The use of the B707 aircraft of the VIP fleet was not considered a feasible option in assisting with the movement of stranded passengers during the dispute. The Government's decision to allow Qantas Airways Ltd and other international carriers to uplift domestic passengers on their normal scheduled domestic sectors facilitated the carriage of passengers experiencing hardship between those ports that the B707 aircraft could service. You would be aware, of course, that an aircraft the size of a B707 is restricted to airports of appropriate standard. These airports are, in the main, those serviced by international operators.

In order to relieve the plight of passengers in outlying regions of Australia the Government gave approval, in principle, for the RAAF to provide services to assist people who were in urgent need to travel for medical, compassionate or other special circumstances, or stranded as a result of the continuation of the strike.

To facilitate this, appropriate arrangements were made with the Queensland and Northern Territory governments. It was also decided to extend RAAF operations to Tasmania and Western Australia if the need arose. However, the provision of daily return services to Tasmania by both Trans- Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia and the timely settlement of the dispute avoided the necessity to adopt these measures.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1384) Senator Walters asked a question without notice concerning the use of the Royal Australian Air Force to take over all flights to Tasmania during any disruptions to interstate flights by strikes and the use of international airlines to carry passengers between Perth and Melbourne on similar occasions.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Approval, in principle, for the RAAF to provide services to people living in outlying regions of Australia was given by the Government during the recent dispute by flight attendants. The RAAF services would have been used to assist people in outlying areas who were in urgent need to travel for medical, compassionate or other special circumstances. RAAF services would also be available to people who had been stranded in outlying areas as a result of the continuation of the strike.

To facilitate this, appropriate arrangements were made with the Queensland and Northern Territory governments. It was also decided to extend RAAF operations to Tasmania and Western Australia if the need arose. The provision of daily return services to Tasmania by both Trans Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia and the timely settlement of the dispute avoided the necessity to adopt these measures.
The use of the RAAF in future disputes will be a matter for consideration by the Government in regard to the circumstances existing at the time.

The Government also requested international airlines serving Australia to consider carrying domestic passengers during the dispute. This request was made when it was found that the effects of the dispute were widespread and was considered necessary in the national interest to relieve the hardship of the many stranded passengers around Australia. International carriers, including Qantas Airways Ltd, were asked to give potential passengers the following priorities:
(a) the carriage of domestic passengers for compassionate reasons, the carriage of Federal Members of Parliament and other VIP's;
(b) the facilitation of international travel by carrying international passengers on domestic journeys to or from connecting international flights;
(c) domestic passengers enduring hardship such as those stranded away from home and having other compelling reasons to travel;
(d) the carriage of other domestic passengers.

Such carriage only applied to those routes served by international carriers in normal scheduled services. International carriers could only carry domestic passengers holding tickets issued by TAA or Ansett and could not issue tickets direct to domestic passengers.
I understand my colleague, the acting Minister for Industrial Relations, has written to you on this matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1548), Senator Colston asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications is prompted by the increasing number of complaints I have received from telephone subscribers who are being harassed by salesmen and women making unsolicited telephone calls to sell their wares. These telephone subscribers object to the privacy of their homes being invaded in this way. Can the Minister advise whether such invasions of privacy can be prevented and, if they cannot be prevented, will the Minister investigate whether some measures can be introduced to stamp out this practice?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I am advised by Telecom Australia that it is aware that there are a number of people who resent this particular form of selling. At the same time, it cannot ignore the fact that the continued operation of these organisations is indicative of another section of the community accepting it as being a legitimate form of selling. Telecom has had discussions with the Australian Direct Marketing Association on the matter and, to date, has received no evidence of unethical sales practices being followed by telephone selling organisations. I appreciate Telecom's view that it is not appropriate for it to be involved in trying to prevent this form of selling bearing in mind that a sizeable section of the community could resent a public authority regulating the manner in which telephone services may be used.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1573) Senator Primmer asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the funding of women's refuges.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1817) Senator Walters asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the employment of social workers in the Commonwealth Public Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1888) Senator Coleman asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer to an interview reported in the West Australian of Wednesday, 6 May, by Allan Veal with Sir Philip Baxter, one of the founders of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission set up by the Menzies Government in 1953. In that interview Sir Philip is reported to have said:
'We need to develop our armed forces and our systems of defence using the most scientific methods that are available-nuclear weapons, chemical and bacteriological warfare.'

In view of the Convention on the Prohibition of the Development, Production and Stockpiling of Bacteriological (Biological) and Toxin Weapons and on their Destruction, ratified by Australia on 5 October 1977, will the Minister clarify the Government's position on this important matter? As Sir Philip Baxter is a person of some note in our community and is even held in high regard by some, will the Minister consider making a public response to his statements to assuage the fears of a large section of the Australian community that we may indeed be committing this country to the future use of such abominations?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Australian policy towards the use of chemical and bacteriological weapons is indicated by its adherence to the 1925 Geneva Protocol for the Prohibition of the Use in War of Asphyxiating, Poisonous or other Gases, and of Bacteriological Methods of Warfare and by its adherence to the convention to which you referred in your question. Australia ratified the latter convention on 5 October 1977 and Parliament passed the Crimes (Biological Weapons) Act in the same year.
No research into the production of chemical and bacteriological weapons is being undertaken, nor is any contemplated.

Australia maintains an interest in chemical and bacteriological warfare, but for defensive purposes only. We engage in limited studies, which are directed towards maintaining a scientific awareness of the effects of chemical and biological warfare agents, the means for their detection and preventive measures against them.
Sir Philip Baxter's views are his own responsibility. If correctly reported they are not views shared by the Australian Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1965) Senator Robertson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Minister representing the Minister for Communications confirm that the Australian Broadcasting Commission in the Northern Territory has been granted autonomy and full State branch status? Recognising that smaller units require much of the same infrastructure as larger units and must have appropriate funding to be effective, will the Minister assure the chamber that sufficient funds will be made available to enable the ABC branch in the Northern Territory to set itself up initially and then to provide the same range of services as is provided in the States? Will the Minister assure the chamber that the Northern Territory stations, particularly the television channels, will not become simply relay stations for southern programs?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The Australian Broadcasting Commission (ABC) is conscious of the needs of the Northern Territory and has been progressively upgrading Northern Territory services over the last two years.

Following a detailed investigation of its operations in the Northern Territory, the ABC has recently decided to give full branch status to the Northern Territory, which will involve the upgrading of the position of Manager, who will work direct to the ABC's General Manager, a progressive review of the classification of several other positions and the creation of a number of new positions, as and when possible. The ABC has also decided to create a Program Officer position to improve local program output.

Northern Territory services are being continually upgraded through the re-introduction of five nights a week television news from Darwin, increased local news and general programming from Alice Springs, the introduction of the remote area TV service, the introduction of 24 hour a day ABC radio and the pilot scheme for Aboriginal broadcasting. Furthermore, the ABC will continue to produce national programs which specifically cover Northern Territory topics, such as a recent program in the popular Big Country series or on current affairs programs such as AM and PM.

The provisions of further services and resources for the Northern Territory will have to be considered in the context of other urgent requirements and the overall funding and staffing levels set for the ABC.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 May 1981 (Hansard, page 2062) Senator Kilgariff asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, without notice, questions concerning Defence Department responsibility for coastal surveillance operations and the utilisation of sea and air operators in future surveillance work.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 May 1981, Senator Sibraa (Hansard, page 2206) and Senator McLaren (Hansard, page 2207) raised questions relating to the use of the Lakeside Hotel, Canberra, for the CHOGM retreat.
