TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 May 1981 (Hansard, page 2146) Senator Geitzelt asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister, a question without notice concerning use by the Commonwealth Government of news services.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister has supplied the following information for answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Commonwealth Government has not requested Australian Associated Press (AAP) to provide information in that Association's possession for use by its intelligence agencies, particularly the Office of National Assessments (ONA).

ONA receives an AAP news service which has been provided to various government departments on a normal commercial basis since 1975. The service that ONA receives is exactly the same as the one that AAP provides to its other clients which, in Canberra, include various embassies.

Needless to say, when AAP sells its news service to government departments it is not engaging in intelligence gathering. And the government departments that buy that service are not, as Senator Geitzelt implies, putting the lives of AAP journalists in danger. In any case, ONA has no intelligence gathering role; it is an assessment body.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 May (Hansard, page 2249) Senator MacGibbon asked the Minister for Finance a question, without notice, concerning what percentage of costs would be recovered from the nations participating in the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister has supplied the following information for answer to the honourable senator's question:
It is not the practice for host governments to recover from other governments the costs incurred in attending Commonwealth Heads of Government meetings.
Nor is it the practice for this Government, or of any previous Australian government, to seek to recover costs from visiting Heads of Government who are guests of the Australian Government.
In line with the practice of other governments who have hosted the Commonwealth Heads of Government meetings:
Accommodation will be provided for each visiting head of delegation and spouse; and accompanying Minister or senior official and spouse; and one other delegation member.
An office will be provided for each delegation at the hotel and at the conference centre.

A car will be provided for each head of delegation and spouse, and one car will be provided for each delegation. There will be a limited pool of cars available for specific purpose journeys related to the Meeting.
Office accommodation will not be charged for, nor normal office facilities including telephones.
Visiting heads of delegations and spouses will not be charged for travel within Australia, and where appropriate travel may be provided for other members of delegations.
Other costs incurred by delegations will be the responsibility of the delegations concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2789) Senator Button asked Senator Carrick, as Leader of the Government in the Senate, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I draw the Minister's attention to reports that the Israeli air force has wiped out a nuclear plant in Iraq which was capable of building nuclear weapons. Can the Minister say which other countries in the Middle East have the capability of building nuclear weapons and which nations in Asia have this capability.
The Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The achievement of a nuclear weapons capability by any country depends upon a political decision to do so and upon its possessing the necessary facilities and the technical ability to fabricate an explosive device based on a critical mass of weapons-grade fissile material.

In terms of the definition provided in the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT), China is the only state in the areas of the Middle East and Asia which is a nuclear weapons state. China is not a party to the NPT.
India, which is also not a party to the NPT, detonated a nuclear explosive device in 1974. India stated that its nuclear test had been for peaceful purposes.

Identification of additional countries which may or may not have a nuclear weapons capability in the Middle East and Asia would involve speculative judgments about the political motivations of these countries. I do not propose to speculate about the political motivations of individual countries.

The following countries in the Middle East and Asia which have nuclear programs are parties to the NPT and have thus accepted the obligation to place all of their nuclear facilities under International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards:

Bangladesh, Egypt, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Japan, Republic of Korea, Libya, Malaysia, Philippines, Thailand. Taiwan, as the Republic of China, deposited an instrument of ratification to the NPT on 27 January 1970 and all of its nuclear facilities are under IAEA safeguards.

The following countries in the Middle East and Asia do not have nuclear programs but are parties to the NPT and have thus accepted the obligation to place any nuclear facilities which they may acquire in the future under IAEA safeguards:
Afghanistan, Democratic Kampuchea, Democratic Yemen, Jordan, Laos, Lebanon, Maldives, Mongolia, Nepal, Singapore, Sri Lanka, Syria.

The Democratic People's Republic of Korea is not a party to the NPT but its research reactor at Nyonpyon and nuclear material for this reactor have been placed under IAEA safeguards. The Socialist Republic of Vietnam is not a party to the NPT but the IAEA is at present considering an agreement under which Vietnam's research reactor at Dalat would be placed under IAEA safeguards.
The following countries in the Middle East and Asia are not parties to the NPT, but do not have nuclear programs:
Bahrain, Bhutan, Burma, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, United Arab Emirates, Yemen Arab Republic. (Kuwait and the Yemen Arab Republic have signed but not ratified the NPT).
